name: Rebecca Oldfield: East Dulwich Lightbox
description:
Light box featuring original destination blind from the discontinued Routemaster London buses. A piece of London history destined to be an antique of the future.

Single destination solid mahogany light boxes, wall mounted, vintage style cable, containing original destination paper.

About Rebecca Oldfield

Becky Oldfield marries the traditional with the contemporary to create an original yet evocative range of products. This contemporary nostalgia has broad appeal and sits comfortably in both traditional and modern surroundings.

Recycling within design is more relevant than ever. Becky's work attempts to look beyond recycling and asks the question "what makes an object worth saving?". Is it purely sentiment that makes us hold onto things? The value we place on objects today has changed. Lost and Found endeavours to reintroduce this sense of value by using forgotten skills and forgotten objects to create new pieces, modern collectables from traditional sources.

‘The devil is in the detail’ Becky is keen to emphasise the heritage of the materials used and the processes by which they are revived as well as celebrating the finished works themselves. The involvement of the client can be key; personal collectables are often incorporated into the work in order to bring a third dimension, a connection with the work, thus hopefully rendering it a desirable object of personal worth.

From source to salvage to studio to home, the whole process is a story Becky thinks deserves to be told.

Delivery

We have this item in stock, expect delivery in 2-5 days.

name: Trevor Burgess: A Place to Live 62
description:
Oil on board
34cm x 41cm

About Trevor Burgess

Recent regional prize winner of the The Discerning Eye, most of Trevor's work is about the ordinary business of living. Trevor is interested in a painting that explores relationships, people, contemporary urban spaces.

Although people tend to be the focus of attention, he is also concerned with the context of social interaction. There are recurring themes in the pictures which fascinate him, such as the interplay of signs within the cityscape, or how urban architecture creates a visually distinctive micro-environment at street level, and how momentary appearances are registered, glimpsed or over-looked in passing by.

Trevor’s work developed over a period of time when he was exploring the use of a less literally descriptive, painterly, figurative language in a series of paintings on the theme of the family, which culminated in some large works done on the MA Fine Art course in Barcelona in 1997/8. After this Trevor moved to London, and felt the need for a more concrete subject and specificity for his work. He turned to the immediate urban environment, and began using his own photographs as source material.

Trevor does not attempt to replicate the conventions of photography. In all representational art there is a gap between what is depicted and how it’s depicted. The peculiar pleasures of painting, for him, are all about this gap.

He uses a glossy liquid paint which brings out the flashes of bright colour that animate urban space. The fluidity, coarseness and texture of the paint contribute to a sense of the thickening of the air in the urban atmosphere, the ambiguity and the discontinuity of visual experience.

The recent series, "A Place to Live" draws on property adverts in newspapers. These paintings use thin glazes directly onto plywood, which absorbs the colour.

About Mia Cavaliero

In her latest work, Mia continues to use the imagery of the forest - dark against light, solid form interspersed with void - to produce something which is made of paint, a veil drawn across the picture plane creating a lattice like pattern. In this painting a restricted palette equally privileges colour and form, allowing optical effects to be explored and accentuated.

name: Gill Rocca: Golden Hour II
description:
oil on canvas, 60x60cm, 2013

About Gill Rocca

For the past 12 years landscape has been the enduring subject of Gill's work. Her recent paintings focus on liminal spaces, when shifts in light have a transformative effect on the landscape and suggest a threshold between the everyday and the extraordinary. The landscapes draw upon observation, memory and invention to present an ambiguous and elusive reality at a point where the familiar is rendered strangely unfamiliar. Always uninhabited, these illusionary scenes are often played out at night; the anonymity of woodland, still lakes and deserted roads, attempting to assimilate themselves into the viewer’s own memories, weaving together narratives of places both real and imagined.

The work varies in size from the intimacy of the miniature pieces on cast resin and panel - the Cabinet Painting series - to monumental scale large landscapes on canvas.

Formal influences shaping Gill's work include the landscapes of German Romantic painters such as Caspar David Friedrich and The Sublime within English Romantic painting to American photographers and filmmakers such as Robert Adams and David Lynch. Her subject matter is directly influenced by Gill's own experience and travel often forms an integral part of the development of new bodies of work.

Delivery

name: Victoria Chalmers: Heather i
description:
92cm x 76cm, oil on canvas.

About Victoria Chalmers

Victoria Chalmers has been working from the figure since her BA at Falmouth School of Art in 1993. She went on to study an MA at the Slade School of Art, where her exploration of portraiture began to further evolve.

Although she has frequently worked to commission, Victoria prefers to choose her own models, as the selection process of the subject is intrinsic to the final painting. Formal influences shaping Victoria’s work include the old masters such as Velasquez to the more contemporary figurative artist, Alice Neel.

Victoria believes the painted portrait still has a great deal to offer as a unique, handmade, often protracted response to the way we look at a face, in contrast to the ever present photographic world.

Victoria has been awarded The Elizabeth Greenshield Foundation award for painting, The Cyril Sweet Award and The Woo Foundation Art Award. Her work is included in the Private Saatchi Collection and has been featured in publications such as ‘Young British Art’ – The Saatchi Decade and ‘The New Neurotic Realism’ The Saatchi Gallery, London

name: Jane Crisp: Sculptural Trugs
description:
These sculptural objects come in three sizes (sizes tbc) and are made of steam bent oak using traditional boat making skills

About Jane Crisp

Taking inspiration from her local Norfolk countryside, history and tradition, flora and fauna, recent graduate Jane Crisp believes that functional objects can be elevated, in very simple ways to create heirlooms and longevity in the designs we live with every day.

Her steam bent oak ‘Trugs’ with their beautifully organic forms show you how this is done. They are inspired by the Norfolk reeds and are made using historic boat building techniques.

With thanks to Katie Treggiden Photography for the wonderful image of Jane's work.

name: Sam Edkins: Bespoke Anatomically Correct Chair
description:
The Anatomically Correct Chair

In these works the designer-maker Sam Edkins makes reference to Memento Mori, a theme often depicted in art and classical antiquity. 

Sam uses imagery sourced from old medical journals which he tailors to suit each antique chair before digitally printing his design on to brushed velvet. As a process this allows Sam to embroider a new history into them and makes each one slightly different. The shape of the chair allows the print to flow into the chair structure, giving a figurative character and seeming to personify the piece.  

Each chair is fully reconditioned and upholstered by Sam with his design.  

About Sam Edkins

Sam Edkins is a London based artist/designer living and working in London.

He studied Fine Art at Goldsmiths College. Sam's work is a combination of the sculptural and the practical.  By working with antique pieces, Sam successfully marries the old with the new, creating something altogether contemporary and bespoke. His work combines traditional craft and technology. 

Taking inspiration from the cabinet of curiosity, museums and personal collections alike, Sam uses them as a source of reference, visually, conceptually and historically. Containing a degree of nostalgia all of his work harks back to a time when knowledge was craved and a desire to understand the world was paramount.

Delivery
-------------------------------------------------------
We have this and a number of other anatomically correct chairs in stock in various designs. Please contact us to for a full list of the works available.     There will be an additional delivery charge for the chairs which will we confirm once your order has been placed.

name: Sam Edkins: Bug Stool
description:
Antique footstool reupholstered in natural, unbleached, cotton canvas featuring digitally manipulated printed images

The Entomology Collection

These pieces take inspiration from the entomology collection of traditional museums and nature itself. The collections traditionally contain vast numbers of insects carefully preserved, pined, categorized and displayed.

In an almost anarchic break from traditional display the bugs contained within the pieces burst out of their petrified state and back to life seeming to move freely across the surface of the works. In turn creating an uneasy sense of chaos and decay to the decadently over stuffed pieces of furniture. Some pieces remain more rigid and true to the museum format; with the traditional buttoning bringing a sense of structure.

The works are all old pieces fully reconditioned and upholstered. As a process this allows Sam to embroider a new history into them and makes each one bespoke. They are chosen for their overstuffed, bourgeois nature, which creates an evocative contrast next to the sense of decay lent by the bugs bursting from the seams freely occupying the pieces. The minimal color palette and simple use of fabric is intended to reflect the under layers of traditionally upholstery which usually remain hidden by heavy top fabrics.

The images are sourced from old natural history journals, adapted and then digitally printed.

About Sam Edkins

Sam completed his BA in Fine Art at Goldsmiths College and has had exhibitions in the Hamburg School of Art (HBFK), Germany, 2010 and the Condemned Exhibition, Hackney Wick, 2009

Delivery

As all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists and designers, delivery may take up to six or this case eight weeks. We will confirm expected delivery and delivery costs once your order has been received.

About Mineheart

Mineheart produces furniture, lighting, wallpaper and interior accessories. The pieces are on the boundary between objects of art and mass produced items and many of the products are made to order or produced in small batches by UK based craftspeople.

Mineheart proudly supports British design and manufacturing. All Mineheart products are produced in the UK by passionate people who enjoy what they do; they hope this love is captured inside their pieces and their quality. 

Mineheart was launched in 2010 by designers Brendan Young and Vanessa Battaglia of Studiomold and Young & Battaglia. The duo is known for their playful approach to design, and innovative re-appropriation of materials and imagery.

name: DJ Lowrie: Reedbeds from Drover's Path to Dunwich
description:
Oil on canvas 45.5 x 35.5 cm, 2013

About DJ Lowrie
---------------------------------------------------------

DJ Lowrie is a painter who is hugely influenced by where she lives. The ever-changing Suffolk sky dominates her work and visually it is the necessary poetry to her life.

The work is less about identifiable and literal representation but more an instinctive and spiritual response to the essential essence of the atmospheric subject.

She starts initially with drawing. It underpins everything she does and is a legacy from her Byam Shaw tutors Oliver Bevan and Nathan Cohen. Through these drawings she explores the relationship of the land and sea to the dramatic coastal skies above her.

Since graduating as a mature student in 1993 DJ Lowrie has exhibited in galleries in Surrey and Hampshire and more latterly in West and East Suffolk

Delivery
---------------------------------------------------------

We work with specialist art handlers to deliver our paintings and wall work. We will confirm expected delivery date and costs once your order has been received.

name: Rowena Brown: Ruined Place on Rock with Tiles
description:
In this new sculptural work Rowena explores the themes of isolation and community, privacy and exposure. By placing the buildings on to rocks the sense of isolation/apartness (like a hermit’s cell) is accentuated. Although the motivation to build on a rock may be to emphasize strength, solidity and safety, these structures show their instability in the face of constant exposure to the elements.

The work is built and sculpted in stoneware clay. It is painted with slips and glazes to create a layered surface of textures and colours.

About Rowena Brown

Rowena’s inspiration comes from media images showing the aftermath of environmental and manmade disruption, and also from weather-worn and derelict structures.

Her handmade ceramic buildings are distinguished by their individual surface texture, marks and features. The forms are part-glazed, then raku or stoneware fired. Each of the pieces has its own character. They can be seen as isolated forms, or as part of a group evoking human interaction and community.

Rowena has a BA in Fashion Design from St. Martins School of Art in London, an MA in Fine Art from the University of Leeds and has exhibited work in California, Yorkshire and London.

Delivery

name: Vanja Bazdulj: Naive Tableware Bat Cups
description:
The Naive Tableware series consists of raw, yet simple, cups, jugs, and vases adorned with the artist's own sketches and doodles.  Inspired by graffiti Vanja observes daily in her stamping ground of Shoreditch, she's created a quirky collection of functional tableware that we just couldn't resist.

Stoneware clay, Food safe glaze, Cup height: cca9cm, Rim diameter: cca7,5cm

About Vanja Bazdulj

Vanja Bazdulj is a London based designer currently focused on making tableware collection in clay.  The practice is largely material driven, influenced by Vanja's backround in architecture, constant research and exploration into form and objects, but most importantly hands on material experiments.

There is a sense of simplicity to all her pieces, which drives the aesthetics and a keen interest in making. Simple forms are highlighted with exposing raw materials, their irregularities and patinas, providing amazing textures, a transparency of working process and an honesty to the finished pieces.

After finishing the faculty of architecture in Ljubljana, Slovenia and working for 2 years as an architect, Vanja decided to do an MA in Furniture Design at The Cass in London and begin her own practice.

Vanja has been designer in residence at The Cass and currently works there as a Project Assistant in the School of Design.

Besides working on private commissions Vanja has worked on commissions from companies such as Anthropologie, smaller independent shops and galleries and has exhibited in numerous exhibitions and design fairs across Europe.

Delivery

name: Ali Miller: Home Sweet Home Milk Jug
description:
Bone China Milk Jug featuring Ali's ever popular Home Sweet Home, UK Map design part of the tea set that was featured in the BBC's Sherlock Holmes series.  

This 18ct gold edged tea set is printed with a map of the British isles accented with old world sailing ships and playful red crowns. Designs that blends classic British imagery together to create a new contemporary style.

Product Info : Fine Bone china, 24 carat gold details
We would recommend that these pieces be hand washed only.
Made, applied and designed in the UK

About Ali Miller

Ali Miller grew up in London and completed her Art Foundation at Camberwell College of Art before going on to Brighton University where she gained a BA (Hons) degree in Fine Art/Sculpture in 2003.

Ali Miller has exhibited widely since graduating, with recent exhibitions and art fairs in London, New York, Chicago, Miami and Paris. Exhibitions include Brave Soldier and Black Butterfly; a solo exhibition at Liberty of London and an exhibition at Skylark, the artist-run gallery at the Oxo Tower on London’s South Bank.

Achievements include a tea set for the Liverpool Tate to support their Alice in Wonderland exhibition, a tea set collection she created for Paul Smith, and a greeting card collection for Liberty of London. Her work has appeared in Company magazine, The Independent on Sunday and Elle Decoration to name but a few.

Ali's work is fundamentally an amalgamation of personal experiences, family history, religion and identity and also the relationship between the individual to the material.

Memory for Ali is a source of euphoric inspiration and, whilst her work might signify a nostalgic reminiscence of years past, it also carries with it the weight of pressures and experience of real life. It is the memories that Ali believes shapes her life and art, first and foremost.

She presents these to the viewer as an aesthetic composition enriched by the use of different textures, material and patterns: the artworks created are an expression of Ali’s design perspective and interest in family history - an unusual combination, but one that succeeds in creating artwork of remarkable intimacy and harmonious composition.

We have this range in stock so delivery should be expected within 2-5 days.

name: Mineheart: Classics Revisited Cushions
description:
Cushions designed by American Artist Chad Wys, cotton satin, backed with black cotton and with feather filled pads, 45 cm x 45 cm

About Chad Wys 

In this collaboration between artist Chad Wys and UK designers Mineheart, the Classics Revisited cushions are based on a series of Chad's paintings called the 'Nocturne' series.  In these works Chad took portraits from the Renaissance era and then openly played with the allure of foreign and aggressive new colors and forms into the otherwise familiar and traditional settings. Barriers and obstacles were created between the viewer and the object through which one must negotiate an understanding of what is both present and hidden.

About Mineheart

Mineheart produces furniture, lighting, wallpaper and interior accessories. The pieces are on the boundary between objects of art and mass produced items and many of the products are made to order or produced in small batches by UK based craftspeople.

Mineheart proudly supports British design and manufacturing. All Mineheart products are produced in the UK by passionate people who enjoy what they do; they hope this love is captured inside their pieces and their quality. 

Mineheart was launched in 2010 by designers Brendan Young and Vanessa Battaglia of Studiomold and Young & Battaglia. The duo is known for their playful approach to design, and innovative re-appropriation of materials and imagery.

name: Judith Tucker: Platform
description:
Oil on canvas, 50cm x 40cm 

About Judith Tucker
About Judith Tucker

Judith’s richly textured paintings of an empty lido in a forest offer spaces for reverie and contemplation. The unoccupied pools invite us to imagine what it would be like to swim there among the cool dark tree. The shimmering, pearlescent surfaces of the paintings echo rippling water and fluttering leaves and almost seem to move.

Judith studied at the Ruskin, University of Oxford and at the University of Leeds, where she is currently Senior Lecturer. Exhibitions include Landscape during times of uncertainty Southampton City Art Gallery, Drawn 2013, RoyalWest of England Academy, shadows traces undercurrents Katherine E. Nash Gallery, Regis Centre for Art Minneapolis USA, Arts and Geographies Exhibition, Lyon, France, Postmemorial Landscapes, Armory Gallery, Blacksburg, Virginia, USA.

name: Adam Kelly: Pharmaceuticals
description:
Gloss on panel, 38cm x 29.5cm, 2013


New Artist Adam Kelly’s paintings explore themes of National Identity. Drawing from his Polish roots, the images combine both nostalgic and historical memories of his time in Warsaw. Adam’s work explores the concept of Modernism, painting on rough wood panels mixing oil with gloss paint, abstraction with figuration to dramatic effect.

About Fliff Carr

name: Gill Rocca: Figment IV
description:
oil on birch ply, 30x30cm, 2013

About Gill Rocca

For the past 12 years landscape has been the enduring subject of Gill's work. Her recent paintings focus on liminal spaces, when shifts in light have a transformative effect on the landscape and suggest a threshold between the everyday and the extraordinary. The landscapes draw upon observation, memory and invention to present an ambiguous and elusive reality at a point where the familiar is rendered strangely unfamiliar. Always uninhabited, these illusionary scenes are often played out at night; the anonymity of woodland, still lakes and deserted roads, attempting to assimilate themselves into the viewer’s own memories, weaving together narratives of places both real and imagined.

The work varies in size from the intimacy of the miniature pieces on cast resin and panel - the Cabinet Painting series - to monumental scale large landscapes on canvas.

Formal influences shaping Gill's work include the landscapes of German Romantic painters such as Caspar David Friedrich and The Sublime within English Romantic painting to American photographers and filmmakers such as Robert Adams and David Lynch. Her subject matter is directly influenced by Gill's own experience and travel often forms an integral part of the development of new bodies of work.

name: Alexena Cayless: Cheaney Chair
description:
Alexena Cayless turned to specialists across Britain to help her create the handsome Cheaney chair. The leather sections, cut and decorated with brogue-style perforations by Cheaney shoes in Northamptonshire, are then stitched to Scottish tweed by a saddlery in Walsall. The beech frame (based on vintage G Plan) is made by a woodworker in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, and the upholstery is done in the East Midlands.

Dimensions: 80cm height, 48 cm width, 47.5cm deep, seat height 45cm

About Alexena Cayless

A trained sculptor and furniture designer, Alexena’s work explores the close relationship between art and design. Her work is influenced by memory and the relationship between people and objects.

Alexena’s background is far from conventional, brought up on a Leicestershire farm, she was introduced to art at an early age by her father, also a trained furniture designer. After graduating from a Fine Art degree Alexena became interested in pursuing a career within the social sector, working in art therapy and then as a paramedic. In 2003 Alexena returned to university to study design. Her work is informed by her experiences of working with people, of gathering stories and wanting to retell narratives through objects.

Alexena’s work is diverse. Her ceramic hip flask and silver chip fork play with ideas regarding the value of objects and reflect her interest in Britishness. Her latest work is inspired by the traditional skills and materials of Midlands based shoemakers and saddlery companies. The companies work in areas of the UK renowned for these manufacturing industries and all of their work is made by hand by skilled craftsmen and women. The Brogue Wingback Armchair has been reupholstered with leather brogue patterns hand-crafted by Cheaney Shoes in Northamptonshire and Scottish Tweed.

Alexena Cayless was Designer in Residence at the Design Museum 2010

Delivery

As all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists and designers, delivery may take up to eight weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

name: Anna Raymond: Knowledge is Power - SOLD
description:
2013, 120cm x 120cm. Digitally printed and screen-printed cotton satin 


About Anna Raymond

Anna uses her practice to examine and challenge the everyday environment.  She highlights over familiar images and icons to reveal an obsessive collection of thoughts, moments and memories. She works to create a visual index of characters which analyse reality by materialising data.

Her energetic, colourful works blur the boundaries between traditional printing techniques and new technologies, merging digital printing and embroidery with more traditional techniques such as screen-printing, flocking and dyeing. The artist’s own excitement about what is possible within the boundaries of printed textiles is evident in the vibrancy of the works themselves.

Anna Raymond followed up her BA in textiles at Goldsmiths College, London in 2000 with a postgraduate apprentice scheme at the Fabric Workshop and Museum, Philadelphia, USA. 

Her exhibitions have included several shows at Contemporary Applied Arts in London,  'Wool House' by the Campaign for Wool, curated by Kit Kemp, Somerset House, Strand, London, Stitched-Up at Crescent Arts, Scarborough (January 2007) as well as Collect at the Victoria and Albert Museum in February 2007. 

Delivery

name: Pia Wustenberg: Small Stacking Vessel
description:
Small Stacking Vessel SVC 
2013
Glass and brass/copper
d 12cm x 20cm h

About Pia Wustenberg

Nominated by Elle Decoration for the British Design Awards 2012, Royal College of Art graduate, Pia Wustenberg produces these gorgeous functional sculptures made from ceramics, glass and wood.

Each of the elements to each sculptural vessel is the fruit of careful craftsmanship: wood turning, metal turning, ceramic throwing and glass blowing form the functional sculptures.

About Pia Wustenberg

A young Finnish-German designer, Pia graduated from Bucks New University in 2008 with a collection of mixed media furniture, having spent her final year focused on wood construction in combination with other materials (ceramic, glass, leather). She completed her postgraduate studies in Design Products at the Royal College of Arts carrying out research into craft and materials in contemporary culture.

Pia strongly believes a curious and observing mind is the main medium in a designer’s toolbox. Her aim is to design objects to contain stories she perceives as relevant today: juxtapositions of materials, surfaces, textures, symbols and colours can unfold to tell new stories through objects, just as letters and words make up the stories in a book. Her current research is concerned with urbanisation as a critical step in cultural evolution. The constant multitude of object experiences and encounters is at its peak in urban environments.

name: Thurle Wright: Wallpaper
description:
Text from William Morris's poem, 'The Earthly Paradise', acid-free glue on paper (2012)

About Thurle Wright

Thurle Wright's delicate, often dizzyingly repetitive and complex paper works stem from an interest in the systems and structures of language, in the ordering of knowledge, and in the storing and accessing words. She transforms pages from books, atlases, dictionaries, and newspapers into small, fragile units and reconstructs them into structures and patterns, creating entirely new meanings.

Her tiny paper shapes capture empty space within walls of text, contorting logical meaning beneath the folds. She creates a space where all that falls outside the system, the non-definable, can exist. Her paper shapes clump together and grow as language - systems simultaneously powerful, rigid, organic, multi-layered, unpredictable and flawed; systems by which we determine our identities and build our worlds.

Born in Zimbabwe, Thurle studied modern languages and literature both in Australia and the UK, before specialising in visual art. She has a BA (Hons) Textiles, from Goldsmiths College, University of London.

Delivery

name: Zichao Hou: Leicester Square Peopleless
description:
2013, Oil on Linen, 75cm x 50cm 	                       

About Zichao Hou

Zichao’s work concerns itself with peace in the world around us and the expression of the very silent moments of his own inner world - those moments when, isolating oneself from the outside, it feels like there is no sound or breath, only the atmosphere created by the scene streaming through. There is a sense of the familiar in his paintings offset by a dreamlike quality of the unfamiliar. The viewer feels a sense of peaceful isolation which is heightened by Zichao’s unique use of colour. His muted hues offers us a view of our world in black and white and while we see hints of human presence in the bins and the electricity pylons, we rarely see people, only animals which seem random and out of place but which are crucial to the ponderous narrative of his ‘story’. This narrative is translated onto the canvas in the form of text from the point of view of a bystander rather like a voiceover in a film. Combining the everyday with the fantastical, the resulting paintings have a beguiling and serene quality which draws the viewer into the story.

Zichao graduated from Central St Martins College of Art and Design last year and just finished his MA in Fine Art at Chelsea College of Art and Design this summer. His work was selected by The Art-Investor.com as ‘one to buy’.

Delivery

We work with specialist art handlers to deliver our paintings and wall work. We will confirm expected delivery date and costs once your order has been received.

name: Dina Varpahovsky: Room 23
description:
Oil on board 120 x120cm
About Dina Varpahovsky

A recent graduate in fine arts at Central St Martins (2012), Dina's work investigates our psychological and emotional relationship with domestic interior and the moments of shifts between the familiar and the uncanny.

The shift occurs when the fallible logic of collage is applied to the painted surface. The cut, the coupage, the bittersweet laceration is both the pleasure of re-ordering the fragments and the pain of losing the whole.

In her rooms architectural laws become suspended, space disintegrates into fragments. The building blocks of her interiors are recognizable but the sum of the parts reads as an alternative to the visible reality.

Dina collects textiles, fabric, images from interiors magazines and incorporates these into her paintings combining both abstraction and figuration, past and present to dramatic effect.

Delivery

We work with specialist art handlers to deliver our paintings and wall work. We will confirm expected delivery date and costs once your order has been received.

In her rooms architectural laws become suspended, space disintegrates into fragments. The building blocks of her interiors are recognizable but the sum of the parts reads as an alternative to the visible reality.

Dina collects textiles, fabric, images from interiors magazines and incorporates these into her paintings combining both abstraction and figuration, past and present to dramatic effect.

name: Angela Charles: West Bay for 9
description:
Acrylic and coloured pencil on framed wooden panel, 15cm x 30cm

About Angela Charles

Angela is very much inspired by her surroundings and from her travels; a certain object or place and its imagined history, a happening or view point which takes her by surprise. 

Rich in texture, Angela uses collage and found pieces in her paintings; the sandpaper, used to sand back layers of paint into the composition, the torn edge of a box used to wipe away paint, all of these things work their way into Angela’s work so that the actual painting itself becomes a historical representation of the painting process.  She works on board, always starting with a base colour, usually a fairly cool pale ground, knowing that it will become part of the work whether it is revealed or not.  In fact Angela will often start a painting inspired by something that by the end has got lost, so absorbed she becomes in the whole process.

Angela studied Fine Art Textiles at Goldsmiths and has regularly exhibits her work in the UK. 

Delivery

We work with specialist art handlers to deliver our paintings and wall work. We will confirm expected delivery date and costs once your order has been received.

name: Jelena Benson: Untitled 1
description:
Oil on canvas, 150x140cm

About Jelena Benson

About Jelena Benson

Influenced by the Abstract Expressionist movement, Latvian artist Jelena Benson’s large scale paintings are concerned with the process of painting.  Jelena approaches the canvas without pre-conceived ideas about colour and frame. Unrestrained by formality, her oil paintings are gestural, fluid and rich in colour.  She approaches the canvases from different points applying new colours and shapes, layer upon layer so there is a sense of infinite space with no sense of centre  She paints spontaneously creating rhythmic and structural movements, responding emotionally to the world around her to create these bold abstract works.   

Jelena has exhibited in Latvia and the UK, including the Whitworth Museum in Manchester.    She has recently had a solo show at the Sayle Gallery in the Isle of Man.

Delivery

name: Ikuko Iwamoto: Spiky Spiky Bowl
description:
Approx 8 cm x 15 cm x 15 cm.

Gorgeous porcelain handcrafted bowl by award winning ceramics designer, Ikuko Iwamoto.  Ikuko looks to microscopic organisms and the tiniest of sea creatures for her inspiration. Every piece is individually handmade – and each of the spikes is attached by hand  - so every one is totally unique.  

About Ikuko Iwamoto

Ikuko makes extremely exquisite and delicately worked cups and other objects. They suggest the everyday, the ordinary, but are in fact rather extra-ordinary. She sees them as being the vehicle to make visible an invisible, microscopic world. A world of intricacy and detail, of mathematical pattern and organic chaos, of beauty and repulsion.

Ikuko graduated from Camberwell College and completed a MA Ceramic and Glass at The Royal College of Art.  She has stacked up numerous awards since she graduated including The Ceramic Review Prize for Innovation at Ceramic Art London in 2009.

Delivery

Please allow two weeks for delivery of this item. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

name: Gill Rocca: Winter Hill (imaginary landscape)
description:
oil on canvas, 130x165cm, 2012

About Gill Rocca

For the past 12 years landscape has been the enduring subject of Gill's work. Her recent paintings focus on liminal spaces, when shifts in light have a transformative effect on the landscape and suggest a threshold between the everyday and the extraordinary. The landscapes draw upon observation, memory and invention to present an ambiguous and elusive reality at a point where the familiar is rendered strangely unfamiliar. Always uninhabited, these illusionary scenes are often played out at night; the anonymity of woodland, still lakes and deserted roads, attempting to assimilate themselves into the viewer’s own memories, weaving together narratives of places both real and imagined.

The work varies in size from the intimacy of the miniature pieces on cast resin and panel - the Cabinet Painting series - to the monumental scale of the large landscapes on canvas like this one featured here.

Formal influences shaping Gill's work include the landscapes of German Romantic painters such as Caspar David Friedrich and The Sublime within English Romantic painting to American photographers and filmmakers such as Robert Adams and David Lynch. Her subject matter is directly influenced by Gill's own experience and travel often forms an integral part of the development of new bodies of work.

Delivery
--------------------------------------------------------

name: Sam Edkins: Anatomically Correct ArmChair new model
description:
The Anatomically Correct Armchair

In these works the designer-maker Sam Edkins makes reference to Memento Mori, a theme often depicted in art and classical antiquity. 

Sam uses imagery sourced from old medical journals which he tailors to suit each antique chair before digitally printing his design on to brushed velvet. As a process this allows Sam to embroider a new history into them and makes each one slightly different. The shape of the chair allows the print to flow into the chair structure, giving a figurative character and seeming to personify the piece.  

Each chair is fully reconditioned and upholstered by Sam with his design.  

About Sam Edkins

Sam Edkins is a London based artist/designer living and working in London.

He studied Fine Art at Goldsmiths College. Sam's work is a combination of the sculptural and the practical.  By working with antique pieces, Sam successfully marries the old with the new, creating something altogether contemporary and bespoke. His work combines traditional craft and technology. 

Taking inspiration from the cabinet of curiosity, museums and personal collections alike, Sam uses them as a source of reference, visually, conceptually and historically. Containing a degree of nostalgia all of his work harks back to a time when knowledge was craved and a desire to understand the world was paramount.

Delivery
-------------------------------------------------------
We have this and a number of other anatomically correct chairs in stock in various designs. Please contact us to for a full list of the works available.     There will be an additional delivery charge for the chairs which will we confirm once your order has been placed.

name: Alice Mara: Affordable Housing Salt & Pepper Pots 6-10
description:
A series of different buildings adorn salt and pepper pots in Alice Mara’s latest “Affordable Housing’ range.  5cm x 3cm  

About Alice Mara

Alice's interest in clay started at the early age of eight at a Saturday morning kid’s club. She went on to do her degree in workshop ceramics at Harrow College and later embarked on a Masters at the Royal College of Art.

The main inspiration for Alice's work is her local environment and the everyday, mundane experiences that occur within it. She walks around armed with her camera ready to catalogue these experiences so that she can incorporate them into her work.

She uses vivid imagery to create an almost utopian sense of place.

Alice's work has been shown at a prestigious exhibition held at Canary Wharfs' Canada Square foyer with nine other ceramic/glass artists. Alice also won the Queensbury Hunt award for most innovative use of ceramic material.

name: Tony Beaver: Medium Tommy Cooper (2013)
description:
(study 2) 34 x 26 cm, oil on canvas, framed

Tony Beaver’s Tommy Cooper paintings portray the moment immediately after Tommy Cooper died on stage when the comedian finds himself in a new and deeply serious space.

About Tony Beaver

An exert from ‘Art Tatty Bye’ a review by Louisa Buck in the Spectator 
‘Tony Beaver is a painter. The people he paints are popular icons, but he is neither a pop artist nor a portraitist. He isn’t po-faced but he doesn’t do irony either. “I love pop art but it’s not my sensibility”. He stresses “I think my paintings are quite physical – not in a macho way, but I want to feel my way in. They’re all images we know really well, but I need to have my own empathy with them. 
Beaver’s on-going preoccupation with the king of Carry On dates from childhood “I remember hearing Kenneth Williams on the radio when I was small and thinking what is this strange thing? We’re all so used to him now, but when you think about him he was such an extraordinary personality-just completely outrageous, we forget how incredibly he is”. But there’s more to these paintings than a recognisable grimace. “I really liked Francis Bacon’s paintings of the screaming pope, and I was also struck by Munch’s “The Scream” when I was younger so I wanted to do a really English version”, he explains. “Bacon’s scream reaches such a point of despair that it disintegrates towards the mouth, and with Munch the whole landscape is a scream. But the difference with Kenneth Williams is that the sound isn’t coming out, it’s going in.”

Whatever Beaver’s feelings for his subjects the source is always specific. Each face comes from a freeze-framed video image, which is then photographed directly from the television screen. These snapshots of blurred gestures and snatched moments lie scattered, crumpled and paint-spotted all over the studio floor. Mention the word photo-realist though, and you get a flinch, and certainly there’s nothing photographic about the end result.

Tony Beaver went to Goldsmiths’ College in the mid-Eighties, just before Hirst and Co. where he was taught by Brit-art mentor Michael Craig Martin.

About Daniel Reynolds

Daniel explores the dichotomy between the traditional and contemporary and the natural and synthetic in his beautiful hand-built porcelain and stoneware work.

He recreates both organic and man-made forms using hand-built moulds to create stunningly natural porecelain forms. Daniel has also been working on these series of beautiful lamps in porcelain and stoneware which give off a wonderful translucent glow.

Daniel has had number of solo shows and is an internationally acclaimed ceramicist, having shown his work in Spain, Venezuela, Sweden and the UK.

name: Daniel Reynolds: Maracaibo Plates
description:
About Daniel Reynolds

Daniel explores the dichotomy between the traditional and contemporary and the natural and synthetic in his beautiful hand-built porcelain and stoneware work.

He recreates both organic and man-made forms using hand-built moulds to create stunningly natural, organically shaped forms. More recently, Daniel has been working on these series of hand built pots in various sizes and glazes.

Daniel's latest series of plates featured here show snapshots of street life in Maracaibo, Venezuela.
 
While spending a few weeks preparing for his gallery show in Caracas, Daniel travelled around the city, camera in hand snapping through the window of his taxi.  

With their distinctive composition and muted hues, the resulting images feel like they belong to another era.  Reminiscent of  stills from 1970s gangster movies, it is hard to believe these images were taken just last month.  This small selection of prototype plates are fresh from the kiln and on show here for the first time. 

Daniel has had number of solo shows and is an internationally acclaimed ceramicist, having shown his work in Spain, Venezuela, Sweden and the UK.

name: Kathy Dalwood: Astronaut
description:
Large plaster bust limited edition of 20, height: 52cms

About Kathy Dalwood

The plaster bust collection

Contemporary re-interpretations of the 18th and 19th century portrait bust, these plaster busts are direct casts from sculptures which Kathy has created from real-life materials and objects.

Rather than sculpting the cloth, hair and lace as in traditional busts, Kathy made costumes from real materials and then cast from these, the plaster picking up all the textured detail of the original.

As the collection has developed Kathy started to look closely at historical head dress and her research led her to the intriguing 18th century fad of decorating hats with very large scale, incongruous objects - famously Marie Antoinette adorned a hat with a huge ship in full sail. She introduced the idea in this sculpture collection, placing architectural monuments, iconic landmarks along with random objects on the hats and costumes.

Delivery

As all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists and designers, delivery may take up to six weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

name: Rowena Brown: Set of 4 Stoneware Houses
description:
Stoneware houses group of four, height from 9-13cm tall

About Rowena Brown

Rowena’s inspiration comes from media images showing the aftermath of environmental and manmade disruption, and also from weather-worn and derelict structures in the Scottish landscape.

Her handmade ceramic buildings are distinguished by their individual surface texture, marks and features. The forms are part-glazed, then raku or stoneware fired. Each of the pieces has its own character. They can be seen as isolated forms, or as part of a group evoking human interaction and community.

Rowena has a BA in Fashion Design from St. Martins School of Art in London, an MA in Fine Art from the University of Leeds and has exhibited work in California, Yorkshire and London.

name: Susanna Lisle: Sumptuous
description:
Sumptuous 
2010 framed
68cm x 92.5cm
watercolour and gouache on paper


About Susanna Lisle

Susanna’s paintings explore colour and geometric pattern. Patterns whether geometric or natural lead the eye in a complex rhythm of entanglement and endlessness. These sensations and ideas are strongly underpinned in her work as she investigates through her use of pattern and colour the playfulness, sumptuousness and beauty of the natural world.

Susanna builds a framework for each painting which is derived from a fascination and research into Islamic pattern, Moorish architecture, Euclidian geometry and mosaic.

Many studies in watercolour and gouache precede the oil paintings. These often become works in their own right.

Susanna’s work is influenced by the works of Philip Taaffe, Beatriz Milhazes and Christine Streuli whose paintings see geometry, traditional ornament and pattern brought to life in a contemporary context.

Susanna Lisle was born in Yorkshire and studied painting at Goldsmiths College of Art, London. She has shown in many group shows, studios and artfairs and has carried out many commissions.

Susanna has just completed her MA in Fine Art at Bath College of Art, Bath.

Sam uses imagery sourced from old medical journals which he tailors to suit each antique chair before digitally printing his design on to brushed velvet. As a process this allows Sam to embroider a new history into them and makes each one slightly different. The shape of the chair allows the print to flow into the chair structure, giving a figurative character and seeming to personify the piece.  

Each chair is fully reconditioned and upholstered by Sam with his design.  

About Sam Edkins

Sam Edkins is a London based artist/designer living and working in London.

He studied Fine Art at Goldsmiths College. Sam's work is a combination of the sculptural and the practical.  By working with antique pieces, Sam successfully marries the old with the new, creating something altogether contemporary and bespoke. His work combines traditional craft and technology. 

Taking inspiration from the cabinet of curiosity, museums and personal collections alike, Sam uses them as a source of reference, visually, conceptually and historically. Containing a degree of nostalgia all of his work harks back to a time when knowledge was craved and a desire to understand the world was paramount.

Delivery
-------------------------------------------------------
We have this and a number of other anatomically correct chairs in stock in various designs. Please contact us to for a full list of the works available.     There will be an additional delivery charge for the chairs which will we confirm once your order has been placed.

name: Sam Edkins: Bug Footstool
description:
Antique footstool reupholstered in natural, unbleached, cotton canvas featuring digitally manipulated printed images		      

The Entomology Collection

These pieces take inspiration from the entomology collection of traditional museums and nature itself. The collections traditionally contain vast numbers of insects carefully preserved, pined, categorized and displayed.

In an almost anarchic break from traditional display the bugs contained within the pieces burst out of their petrified state and back to life seeming to move freely across the surface of the chairs. In turn creating an uneasy sense of chaos and decay to the decadently over stuffed pieces of furniture. Some pieces remain more rigid and true to the museum format; with the traditional buttoning bringing a sense of structure.

The chairs are old pieces fully reconditioned and upholstered. As a process this allows me to embroider a new history into them and makes each one bespoke. They are chosen for their overstuffed, bourgeois nature, which creates an evocative contrast next to the sense of decay lent by the bugs bursting from the seams freely occupying the pieces. The minimal color palette and simple use of fabric is intended to reflect the under layers of traditionally upholstery which usually remain hidden by heavy top fabrics.

The images are sourced from old natural history journals, adapted and then digitally printed.

About Sam Edkins

Sam completed his BA in Fine Art at Goldsmiths College and has had exhibitions in the Hamburg School of Art (HBFK), Germany, 2010 and the Condemned Exhibition, Hackney Wick, 2009

Delivery

As all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists and designers, delivery may take up to six or this case eight weeks. We will confirm expected delivery and delivery costs once your order has been received.

name: Alison Griffin: Not A Place To Dwell II
description:
45 X 36 cm Graphite and pencil on greaseproof paper and paper, framed in a white frame

About Alison Griffin

The way Alison perceives a place, and the sensations evoked by her surroundings, no matter how fleeting, have been informed and shaped throughout her life, but especially from her childhood memories (whether real or imagined), dream events and certain films she avidly absorbed on TV as a child. She has integrated and assimilated all these experiences and they are revealed in the emotions she feels towards her immediate surroundings, and how this inhabited, domestic space can feel alien, hostile and uncanny. The places she chooses to depict in her work therefore always resonate on a personal level, maybe capturing a nuance of an old family home, a moment from a recurring dream or perhaps a familiar feeling generated from a scene from an old film. She is interested in evoking an unnatural tension in the human living space, a voyeuristic unease similar to that experienced in a black and white Alfred Hitchcock film noir, or a David Lynch film, the feeling that someone or some presence is lurking in the shadows, watching and waiting. Scenes partly obscured by trees, branches and fences/walls, and cropped viewpoints and camera angles heighten this tension and create a sense of dislocation. The resultant images, resembling snapshots or film stills, can be read as individual scenes, a complete picture. On the other hand, the intimate composition of the drawings asks the viewer to look closer and deeper, enticing them to enter into a much bigger narrative, to consider the entire ‘film’ and question the everyday places we take for granted.

name: Susan Spencer Hayter: Sea lily collection xi
description:
oil on board, 16 x 9.5cm

These small and very beautiful sea lily paintings make reference to the scientific study of their fossilised remains, behind the scenes at the Natural History Museum. Painted in oil on panels, this traditional medium references, historically, the still life genre of painters such as Giorgio Morandi and J.S. Chardin.

About Susan Spencer

Having worked and studied previously as a Biologist and in education, Susan combines a passion for the natural world and environmental issues with artistic concerns, in order to explore the boundaries between the two.

The main body of work has arisen following research, at the Natural History Museum, into Sea Lilies or ‘crinoids’, a group of marine organisms with a plant-like structure, inhabiting oceans worldwide for over 500 million years. Referencing both scientific and artistic traditions in combining close observational studies with paintings and prints, the artist hopes to awaken a sense of awe and wonder towards the natural world as well as reflection upon the challenges it faces.

Susan Spencer graduated in Fine Art Painting from Wimbledon School of Art in 2006 and currently paints in London.

name: Kathy Dalwood: L'ingénieure
description:
Plaster Bust 44cm high

About Kathy Dalwood

The plaster bust collection

Contemporary re-interpretations of the 18th and 19th century portrait bust, these plaster busts are direct casts from sculptures which Kathy has created from real-life materials and objects.

Rather than sculpting the cloth, hair and lace as in traditional busts, Kathy made costumes from real materials and then cast from these, the plaster picking up all the textured detail of the original.

As the collection has developed Kathy started to look closely at historical head dress and her research led her to the intriguing 18th century fad of decorating hats with very large scale, incongruous objects - famously Marie Antoinette adorned a hat with a huge ship in full sail. She introduced the idea in this sculpture collection, placing architectural monuments, iconic landmarks along with random objects on the hats and costumes.

Delivery

As all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists and designers, delivery may take up to six weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

name: Gill Rocca: Nowhere IV
description:
Nowhere IV, oil on woodblock, 10x10cm, (framed 32x32cm), 2012

About Gill Rocca 
--------------------------------------------------------
For the past 12 years landscape has been the enduring subject of Gill's work. Her recent paintings focus on liminal spaces, when shifts in light have a transformative effect on the landscape and suggest a threshold between the everyday and the extraordinary. The landscapes draw upon observation, memory and invention to present an ambiguous and elusive reality at a point where the familiar is rendered strangely unfamiliar. Always uninhabited, these illusionary scenes are often played out at night; the anonymity of woodland, still lakes and deserted roads, attempting to assimilate themselves into the viewer’s own memories, weaving together narratives of places both real and imagined.

The work varies in size from the intimacy of the miniature pieces on cast resin and panel - the Cabinet Painting series - to the monumental scale of the large landscapes on canvas. The Cabinet Paintings allude to the tradition of intimate and secretive collections of small works made popular in the 15th C in Europe.

Formal influences shaping Gill's work include the landscapes of German Romantic painters such as Caspar David Friedrich and The Sublime within English Romantic painting to American photographers and filmmakers such as Robert Adams and David Lynch. Her subject matter is directly influenced by Gill's own experience and travel often forms an integral part of the development of new bodies of work.

name: Simon Ledson: Timescape 4
description:
25 x 30 cm, oil on canvas, framed

About Simon Ledson

Painter Simon Ledson's ‘Timescapes’ explore the visual perception of atmospheric changes, the reflection of light on a landscape or a seascape. Simon is particularly captivated by the effect of the nautical dawn, the time at which there is enough sunlight for the horizon and some objects to be distinguishable; when the sun is 12 degrees below the horizon in the morning. Simon is based in the South West and regularly exhibits throughout the UK.

name: Pia Wustenberg: Raku Fired Stacking Vessels
description:
Coming soon are these beautiful Raku Stacking Vessels by Pia. 

A series of functional sculptures for the home, each Vessel is an individual piece, combining three crafts processes and materials.
Raku ceramics are achieved through a beautiful process of smoke firing.

After the ceramic is bisqued, a glaze is applied and fired in a gas kiln achieving about 1000ºC. At this temperature the ceramic is taken out and covered with wood chips. The resulting smoke and thermal shock affect the glaze surface to an uneven and craqueled finish.

Each piece in the Raku series is unique.

We are featuring these vessels at our next show in May and will have them available for purchase online shortly.

name: Richard Brendon: Reason cup and saucer
description:
Reason: Saucer: bone china, inglaze cobalt blue and 24 carat burnished gold gilding – 15cm diameter Cup: bone china, inglaze cobalt blue and 24 carat burnished gold gilding – L 11cm x D 8.5cm x H 7cm

About Richard Brendon:

Richard Brendon's latest work which he has developed with Patternity.

The collaboration includes two different cup and saucer combinations – “Warp” and “Reason”. Warp, a bold striped pattern saucer paired with Richard’s highly sought after platinum Reflect cup, which reflects and warps the lines into an ever changing and memorizing pattern. Reason features the same patterned saucer, striped back to the base cobalt print and paired with a simply decorated cup that intelligently combines printed and hand painted elements.

The cup and saucer draws inspiration from over two centuries of British tea-ware and the resulting shape is historically informed, but elegant and modern.

A series of different buildings adorn salt and pepper pots in Alice Mara’s latest “Affordable Housing’ range.  7.5cm x 3cm £30  

About Alice Mara

Alice's interest in clay started at the early age of eight at a Saturday morning kid’s club. She went on to do her degree in workshop ceramics at Harrow College and later embarked on a Masters at the Royal College of Art.

The main inspiration for Alice's work is her local environment and the everyday, mundane experiences that occur within it. She walks around armed with her camera ready to catalogue these experiences so that she can incorporate them into her work.

She uses vivid imagery to create an almost utopian sense of place.

Alice's work has been shown at a prestigious exhibition held at Canary Wharfs' Canada Square foyer with nine other ceramic/glass artists. Alice also won the Queensbury Hunt award for most innovative use of ceramic material.

name: Simon Ledson: Somerset Unfolding 6:10/5
description:
Somerset Unfolding 6 -10/5 oil on linen 152cm x 92cm 

About Simon Ledson

Painter Simon Ledson will be presenting ‘Timescapes’ his latest works which explore the visual perception of atmospheric changes, the reflection of light on a landscape or seascape. Simon is particularly captivated by the effect of the nautical dawn, the time at which there is enough sunlight for the horizon and some objects to be distinguishable; when the sun is 12 degrees below the horizon in the morning.

name: Gillian Cutbill: Departure
description:
Departure, 20cms (wide) x 30 cms (high) mixed media on glass.

About Gillian Cutbill

Gill is interested in the transformative power of light. Transparent and reflective surfaces in the contemporary environment and reflected images are a frequent theme. In transit, reflections are glimpsed at speed, suggesting the voyeurism of film. The imagery is strongly allied to photography and cinema and quotes from the vocabulary of film: blurring, freezing action, framing and long exposure. Materials include paint, glass, mirror, found objects and transfer prints.

Gill has exhibited widely and has curated a number of exhibitions in non-art spaces. Her work is in many corporate and private collections. She also works as a freelance audio describer for the blind, as a teacher and as an Artist Educator for both London's Tate Galleries.

Delivery

We work with specialist art handlers to deliver our paintings and wall work. We will confirm expected delivery date and costs once your order has been received.

name: Sam Edkins: Heart Cushion
description:
These cushions like Sam's Anatomically Correct Chairs make reference to Memento Mori, a theme often depicted in art and Classical antiquity. 

The images are sourced from old medical journals. They are adapted and then digitally printed on heavy cotton canvas. 

Each cushion is 41cmx 45cm and is backed with a cotton velvet.

About Sam Edkins 
Sam's work is a combination of the sculptural and the practical. Marrying the old with the new to create something contemporary and bespoke.  Containing a degree of nostalgia the work harks back to a time when knowledge was craved and a desire to understand the world was paramount.

Sam completed his BA in Fine Art at Goldsmiths College and has had exhibitions in the Hamburg School of Art (HBFK), Germany, 2010 and the Condemned Exhibition, Hackney Wick, 2009

Delivery
We have a small number of these cushions in stock but as all of our items are bespoke, if we are out of stock orders may take up to six weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

name: Dina Varpahovsky: Room no 14
description:
Oil on Wood, 80cm X 80cm

About Dina Varpahovsky

A recent graduate in fine arts at Central St Martins (2012), Dina's work investigates our psychological and emotional relationship with domestic interior and the moments of shifts between the familiar and the uncanny.

The shift occurs when the fallible logic of collage is applied to the painted surface. The cut, the coupage, the bittersweet laceration is both the pleasure of re-ordering the fragments and the pain of losing the whole.

In her rooms architectural laws become suspended, space disintegrates into fragments. The building blocks of her interiors are recognizable but the sum of the parts reads as an alternative to the visible reality.

Dina collects textiles, fabric, images from interiors magazines and incorporates these into her paintings combining both abstraction and figuration, past and present to dramatic effect.

Delivery

We work with specialist art handlers to deliver our paintings and wall work. We will confirm expected delivery date and costs once your order has been received.

name: Melanie Porter: Hugo Quod Cushion
description:
Melanie's Hugo cushions are knitted on giant knitting needles, specially made for her. The yarn is 100% merino wool which is painstakingly hand prepared to create a truly unique soft felted yarn. The cushion comes with a 100% feather cushion pad and black cotton canvas back. Available in Amber, Soft Grey, Apple, Hot Pink, Soft White and Black.

Delivery 10 days | 45cm x 45cm

About Melanie Porter

After 10 years working as a knitwear designer for a number of international fashion brands, in 2008 Melanie Porter turned her expertise to furniture and soft furnishings, creating one-off contemporary designs that are destined to be family heirlooms.

Trained at the prestigious Central Saint Martin’s College, Melanie’s ability to create exquisite, textured fabrics which are individually knitted and felted for every project has drawn attention from clients and press all over the world.

Through her work she explores the use of traditional craft techniques to create products with a contemporary aesthetic.

Delivery

As all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists and designers, delivery may take up to six weeks. These particular items should be ready for dispatch however within 10 days. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received

name: Alexena Cayless: Brogue Wingback Armchair
description:
Beautifully crafted, wingback armchair 
Dimensions: 95 cm height, 76 cm width, 80 cm depth

Made with a Parker Knoll frame, Scottish Shooting Tweed and leather brogue patterns. 

About Alexena Cayless

A trained sculptor and furniture designer, Alexena’s work explores the close relationship between art and design. Her work is influenced by memory and the relationship between people and objects.

Alexena’s background is far from conventional, brought up on a Leicestershire farm, she was introduced to art at an early age by her father, also a trained furniture designer. After graduating from a Fine Art degree Alexena became interested in pursuing a career within the social sector, working in art therapy and then as a paramedic. In 2003 Alexena returned to university to study design. Her work is informed by her experiences of working with people, of gathering stories and wanting to retell narratives through objects.

Alexena’s work is diverse. Her ceramic hip flask and silver chip fork play with ideas regarding the value of objects and reflect her interest in Britishness. Her latest work is inspired by the traditional skills and materials of Midlands based shoemakers and saddlery companies. The companies work in areas of the UK renowned for these manufacturing industries and all of their work is made by hand by skilled craftsmen and women. The Brogue Wingback Armchair has been reupholstered with leather brogue patterns hand-crafted by Cheaney Shoes in Northamptonshire and Scottish Tweed.

Alexena Cayless was Designer in Residence at the Design Museum 2010

Delivery

As all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists and designers, delivery may take up to eight weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

name: Alison Griffin: The Last Place You Thought I Would Be Nr 3
description:
Pen and graphite on paper and greaseproof paper size tbc

Alison’s work explores the notion of home, not as an intimate, secure sanctuary, but as an uncanny place of fear, provoking the viewer to question the hidden secrets that lurk behind the curtains of domesticity, and the relationship between inside and outside of home – where is it safe?

By taking old photographs and memorabilia and putting them with ideas taken from real events and dreams from the past, Alison produces well-executed drawings of unsettling scenes that have a cinematic feel. The viewpoint of each piece is low, as seen by a child, and wallpaper featured is suggestive of a family home. It would be easy to view these works as sinister, the series title suggests otherwise and immediately challenges our perception of the pieces. Each piece is named ‘The Last Place You Thought I Would Be’, in doing os Alison transports us back to our own childhood home, instigating emotions from the time, perhaps the daunting prospect of life beyond the house.

Alison graduated from Central Saint Martins in 2012 with a BA (Hons) in Fine art, where her work was described by Jonathan Jones of The Guardian as ‘curious and memorable’ when he saw it at the final year show. While still studying, Alison had her work included in a number of group shows around London, including Chateau D’lf at Shoreditch Town Hall in 2009 and at the OXO in 2011. She was selected for the Clyde & Co. Art Award in 2012 as part of their Community Investment programme to support and mentor emerging artists.

name: Pia Wustenberg:  Red Stacking Vessels
description:
Nominated by Elle Decoration for the British Design Awards 2012, Royal College of Art graduate, Pia Wustenberg produces these gorgeous functional sculptures made from ceramics, glass and wood.

Each of the 3 elements to each sculptural vessel is the fruit of careful craftsmanship: wood turning, ceramic throwing and glass blowing form the functional sculptures. The individual components are positioned into one another, the wood being burned to fit into the hot glass profile, to create a single piece.

About Pia Wustenberg

A young Finnish-German designer, Pia graduated from Bucks New University in 2008 with a collection of mixed media furniture, having spent her final year focused on wood construction in combination with other materials (ceramic, glass, leather). She completed her postgraduate studies in Design Products at the Royal College of Arts carrying out research into craft and materials in contemporary culture.

Pia strongly believes a curious and observing mind is the main medium in a designer’s toolbox. Her aim is to design objects to contain stories she perceives as relevant today: juxtapositions of materials, surfaces, textures, symbols and colours can unfold to tell new stories through objects, just as letters and words make up the stories in a book. Her current research is concerned with urbanisation as a critical step in cultural evolution. The constant multitude of object experiences and encounters is at its peak in urban environments.

Delivery

As all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists and designers, delivery may take up to six to eight weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

name: Susan Spencer Hayter: Uperocrinus iii
description:
Oil on gilded panel
23 x 11.5 x 2 cm

About Susan Spencer

Having worked and studied previously as a Biologist and in education, Susan combines a passion for the natural world and environmental issues with artistic concerns, in order to explore the boundaries between the two.

The main body of work has arisen following research, at the Natural History Museum, into Sea Lilies or ‘crinoids’, a group of marine organisms with a plant-like structure, inhabiting oceans worldwide for over 500 million years. Feeding on oil-rich plankton, crinoids are particularly pertinent to current concerns regarding pollution and fossil fuels: their fossilised remains are often used as indicators in oil exploration. Referencing both scientific and artistic traditions in combining close observational studies with paintings and prints, the artist hopes to awaken a sense of awe and wonder towards the natural world as well as reflection upon the challenges it faces.

Intimate works, painted in oil on gilded gessoed panels, are made using the traditional labour-intensive techniques of sacred Byzantine icons. They pay homage, instead, to crinoids, as part of the fragile world.

The prints refer to both living and fossilised crinoids forms and the historical use of this medium in making scientific records, whilst exploring a variety of techniques used as a means of expression. This takes a more romantic path in the series of monoprints, devoted to the environmental fragility of these creatures.

Susan Spencer graduated in Fine Art Painting from Wimbledon School of Art in 2006 and currently paints in London.

Delivery

name: Kathy Dalwood: Zoro
description:
Plaster bust height 33cm

About Kathy Dalwood

The plaster bust collection

Contemporary re-interpretations of the 18th and 19th century portrait bust, these plaster busts are direct casts from sculptures which Kathy has created from real-life materials and objects.

Rather than sculpting the cloth, hair and lace as in traditional busts, Kathy made costumes from real materials and then cast from these, the plaster picking up all the textured detail of the original.

As the collection has developed Kathy started to look closely at historical head dress and her research led her to the intriguing 18th century fad of decorating hats with very large scale, incongruous objects - famously Marie Antoinette adorned a hat with a huge ship in full sail. She introduced the idea in this sculpture collection, placing architectural monuments, iconic landmarks along with random objects on the hats and costumes.

Delivery

As all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists and designers, delivery may take up to six weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

name: Trevor Burgess: Fish Stall
description:
Recent regional prize winner of the The Discerning Eye, most of Trevor's work is about the ordinary business of living. Trevor is interested in a painting that explores relationships, people, contemporary urban spaces.

Although people tend to be the focus of attention, he is also concerned with the context of social interaction. There are recurring themes in the pictures which fascinate him, such as the interplay of signs within the cityscape, or how urban architecture creates a visually distinctive micro-environment at street level, and how momentary appearances are registered, glimpsed or over-looked in passing by.

Trevor’s work developed over a period of time when he was exploring the use of a less literally descriptive, painterly, figurative language in a series of paintings on the theme of the family, which culminated in some large works done on the MA Fine Art course in Barcelona in 1997/8. After this Trevor moved to London, and felt the need for a more concrete subject and specificity for his work. He turned to the immediate urban environment, and began using his own photographs as source material.

Trevor does not attempt to replicate the conventions of photography. In all representational art there is a gap between what is depicted and how it’s depicted. The peculiar pleasures of painting, for him, are all about this gap.

He uses a glossy liquid paint which brings out the flashes of bright colour that animate urban space. The fluidity, coarseness and texture of the paint contribute to a sense of the thickening of the air in the urban atmosphere, the ambiguity and the discontinuity of visual experience.

In his market stalls series, he explores how every shop and market stall trying to sell you something is wanting to catch your eye. Most of the intense colour on the street is there for that reason. In that way the paintings come to him ready-made: somebody has already done the composing. You could think of the shopper as the spectator, and the shop display as the painting within the painting. Or, with the drapery of the awnings and the stall coverings, aren't the market stalls like little theatres?

In the recent paintings Trevor found himself going back to an idea he originally had in painting the Wholesale Fruit and Veg paintings: to make visible that the aesthetics of painting has the same origin and purposes as the structures pervading communication and display in everyday life.

He uses a glossy liquid paint which brings out the flashes of bright colour that animate urban space. The fluidity, coarseness and texture of the paint contribute to a sense of the thickening of the air in the urban atmosphere, the ambiguity and the discontinuity of visual experience.

In his market stalls series, he explores how every shop and market stall trying to sell you something is wanting to catch your eye. Most of the intense colour on the street is there for that reason. In that way the paintings come to him ready-made: somebody has already done the composing. You could think of the shopper as the spectator, and the shop display as the painting within the painting. Or, with the drapery of the awnings and the stall coverings, aren't the market stalls like little theatres?

In the recent paintings Trevor found himself going back to an idea he originally had in painting the Wholesale Fruit and Veg paintings: to make visible that the aesthetics of painting has the same origin and purposes as the structures pervading communication and display in everyday life.

name: Trevor Burgess: A place to live 42
description:
Oil on board 39 x 39cm

About Trevor Burgess

Recent regional prize winner of the The Discerning Eye, most of Trevor's work is about the ordinary business of living. Trevor is interested in a painting that explores relationships, people, contemporary urban spaces.

Although people tend to be the focus of attention, he is also concerned with the context of social interaction. There are recurring themes in the pictures which fascinate him, such as the interplay of signs within the cityscape, or how urban architecture creates a visually distinctive micro-environment at street level, and how momentary appearances are registered, glimpsed or over-looked in passing by.

Trevor’s work developed over a period of time when he was exploring the use of a less literally descriptive, painterly, figurative language in a series of paintings on the theme of the family, which culminated in some large works done on the MA Fine Art course in Barcelona in 1997/8. After this Trevor moved to London, and felt the need for a more concrete subject and specificity for his work. He turned to the immediate urban environment, and began using his own photographs as source material.

Trevor does not attempt to replicate the conventions of photography. In all representational art there is a gap between what is depicted and how it’s depicted. The peculiar pleasures of painting, for him, are all about this gap.

He uses a glossy liquid paint which brings out the flashes of bright colour that animate urban space. The fluidity, coarseness and texture of the paint contribute to a sense of the thickening of the air in the urban atmosphere, the ambiguity and the discontinuity of visual experience.

The recent series, "A Place to Live" draws on property adverts in newspapers. These paintings use thin glazes directly onto plywood, which absorbs the colour.
