name: Felicia Strehemel: Red Tunnel
description:
Handmade vintage lightbox made from reclaimed vintage drawers. Image taken from the red ribbed pedestrian walkway and cycle path in Finnieston, Glasgow, Scotland

Approx Size: W:71.5cm H:36cm D:15cm

About Felicia Strehemel

Artist and designer Felicia Strehmel was born and raised in Berlin. While she is happily settled in London she remains a Berliner at heart. and it is this nostalgia and challenge of conventional ways of viewing objects which act as a recurring and often humorous theme throughout her work.

A passionate amateur photographer, her work amalgamates old crafts such as decoupage and furniture restoration with modern image manipulation.

Her lightboxes aim to revive the craftsmanship inherent in period chest of drawers from the 1900s to the 1960s, and work with the charm and character of these weathered woods, while the subtly translucent image slides capture moments of ephemeral beauty, at times reminiscent of period past, at times playful and dreamy.

All Lightboxes are made from period chests of drawers and handmade acrylic photo slides featuring images and thoughts that appear to float in glass, giving them a depth and colour saturation that draws its viewer in.

While some drawers are restored to their original beauty, others are left with historic marks or changed entirely to give them a new lease of life. Large light boxes are made from the cross-section of an entire chest of drawers and can be up to 120cm x 120cm in size.

Vintage fabric cable further complements the overall appearance of each Lightbox and a note featured in fitting antique brass frames tells a story of its journey.

All traditional electrical fittings are produced by small British companies and are fitted, tested and CE certified to be used with energy efficient CFL light bulbs up to 20W. The image slides are installed in such a way that they can be easily slid up and down to exchange the bulb. Brass mirror plates are fitted to the back of each light-box so that they can be hung safely.

Delivery

While delivery may be within 2-5 days, because all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists/designers, delivery may take up to six weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received

name: Dina Varpahovsky: Room no 11
description:
Oil on wood, 50 x 50 cm

About Dina Varpahovsky

A recent graduate in fine arts at Central St Martins (2012), Dina's work investigates our psychological and emotional relationship with domestic interior and the moments of shifts between the familiar and the uncanny. 

The shift occurs when the fallible logic of collage is applied to the painted surface. The cut, the coupage, the bittersweet laceration is both the pleasure of re-ordering the fragments and the pain of losing the whole. 

In her rooms architectural laws become suspended, space disintegrates into fragments. The building blocks of her interiors are recognizable but the sum of the parts reads as an alternative to the visible reality.	

Dina collects textiles, fabric, images from interiors magazines and incorporates these into her paintings combining both abstraction and figuration, past and present to dramatic effect.

Delivery

We work with specialist art handlers to deliver our paintings and wall work. We will confirm expected delivery date and costs once your order has been received.

name: Pia Wustenberg: Stacking Vessels India
description:
Material: Copper/Brass, Glass and Wood
Height: ca. 400mm

Nominated by Elle Decoration for the British Design Awards 2012, Royal College of Art graduate, Pia Wustenberg produces these gorgeous functional sculptures made from copper, glass and wood.  

This work was designed for 'Inspired by India' an exhibition of Contemporary Design at Southeby's in May 2012.

Each of the 3 elements to each sculptural vessel is the fruit of careful craftsmanship. The individual components are positioned into one another with careful precision. 

About Pia Wustenberg

A young Finnish-German designer, Pia graduated from Bucks New University in 2008 with a collection of mixed media furniture, having spent her final year focused on wood construction in combination with other materials (ceramic, glass, leather). She completed her postgraduate studies in Design Products at the Royal College of Arts carrying out research into craft and materials in contemporary culture.

Pia strongly believes a curious and observing mind is the main medium in a designer’s toolbox. Her aim is to design objects to contain stories she perceives as relevant today: juxtapositions of materials, surfaces, textures, symbols and colours can unfold to tell new stories through objects, just as letters and words make up the stories in a book.  Her current research is concerned with urbanisation as a critical step in cultural evolution. The constant multitude of object experiences and encounters is at its peak in urban environments.


Delivery
As all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists and designers, delivery may take up to six to eight weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

name: Pia Wustenberg: Stacking Vessels
description:
Materials: wood, glass and ceramic
Height: ca 35cm

Nominated by Elle Decoration for the British Design Awards 2012, Royal College of Art graduate, Pia Wustenberg produces these gorgeous functional sculptures made from ceramics, glass and wood.  

Each of the 3 elements to each sculptural vessel is the fruit of careful craftsmanship: wood turning, ceramic throwing and glass blowing form the functional sculptures. The individual components are positioned into one another, the wood being burned to fit into the hot glass profile, to create a single piece.

The qualities of the different materials become emphasised in their shadow.

About Pia Wustenberg

A young Finnish-German designer, Pia graduated from Bucks New University in 2008 with a collection of mixed media furniture, having spent her final year focused on wood construction in combination with other materials (ceramic, glass, leather). She completed her postgraduate studies in Design Products at the Royal College of Arts carrying out research into craft and materials in contemporary culture.

name: Louis Blondiau: Figure with a book
description:
90cm x 80cm oil on canvas

About Louis Blondiau

Louis Blondiau's paintings represent different views, animated by the presence of a human figure seen  from  the  back,  staring  at  the landscape.  Except  for  the fact  that  they  seem  to  be  looking  at it,  these  figures  do  not appear  to  have  a  functional  link  with the  scenery  in  front  of them.  On  the   contrary,  they  seem  to  be suspended  in  some sort  of  mysterious,  almost  metaphysical, space, time and dimension.

Delivery

name: Louis Blondiau: Interior on Purple
description:
60cm x 40cm oil on linen

About Louis Blondiau

Louis Blondiau's paintings represent different views, animated by the presence of a human figure seen  from  the  back,  staring  at  the landscape.  Except  for  the fact  that  they  seem  to  be  looking  at it,  these  figures  do  not appear  to  have  a  functional  link  with the  scenery  in  front  of them.  On  the   contrary,  they  seem  to  be suspended  in  some sort  of  mysterious,  almost  metaphysical, space, time and dimension.

Delivery

We work with specialist art handlers to deliver our paintings and wall work. Please contact us debra@cavalierofinn.com with your address if you would like to purchase this painting and we will confirm expected delivery date and costs once your email has been received.

name: Caroline Popham: Silhouettes
description:
These gorgeous Silhouettes make an ideal birthday or anniversary gift for close family or friends.  

Priced from £75 for a minimum of two silhouettes and an additional £25 per silhouette, they are supplied unframed.  Please contact us should you wish to commission more than 10 silhouettes.

Cavaliero Finn can supply the piece in a floating frame for an additional £25.  Antique frames can also be sourced and will be priced individually.

About Caroline Popham

Caroline's work is a modern take on the silhouette cuts first introduced as an art form in the 18th Century. Silhouettes immediately capture the essence of a person in a graphic way. There is an instant connection in recognising a face recreated in the simplest of forms. Photographs are supplied and then graphically redrawn to create contemporary silhouettes. It is an interactive process with clients being able to add text and colour choices if required. Trained as a graphic designer (University of Brighton) Caroline is particularly interested in illustration, paper and hand drawn type. Caroline has designed for many different companies including Jigsaw, Anya Hindmarch, Chinti and Parker and Laura Lee Jewellery. 

Delivery

Because these items are bespoke and made to order by our artists/designers, delivery may take up to six weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

name: Alice Mara: Swimmer Cup and Saucer
description:
Having acquired herself a ticket to Olympic synchronized swimming event, an idea was sparked in the creative mind of ceramicist Alice Mara. Inspired by the way synchronized swimmers create patterns and regimentation with their bodies, she set about working up some new designs. She wanted the viewer to see at first glance an ornate pattern, then on closer inspection see the group of elegant synchronized swimmers.

As with all of her work, Alice asked a friend to pose for a 50’s inspired swimming photoshoot, having ordered a vintage swimming cap from ebay. She was pleased with the outcome because the imagery immediately took on the feel of swimmers from a bygone era, but with a contemporary twist.

About Alice Mara

Alice's interest in clay started at the early age of eight at a Saturday morning kid’s club. She went on to do her degree in workshop ceramics at Harrow College and later embarked on a Masters at the Royal College of Art.

The main inspiration for Alice's work is her local environment and the everyday, mundane experiences that occur within it. She walks around armed with her camera ready to catalogue these experiences so that she can incorporate them into her work.

She uses vivid imagery to create an almost utopian sense of place.

Alice's work has been shown at a prestigious exhibition held at Canary Wharfs' Canada Square foyer with nine other ceramic/glass artists. Alice also won the Queensbury Hunt award for most innovative use of ceramic material.

Delivery

While delivery will usually be within 2-5 days, because all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists/designers, delivery may take up to six weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

name: Liz Emtage - Summer grasses lamp
description:
These stunning translucent bone china lamps are inspired
by Liz's happy childhood memories of relaxing in meadows on hot
summer afternoons. 

They are slip cast in the UK.  Because of the way the clay moves in the kiln, each lamp is slightly different in form. The lamps have a bayonet bulb fitting, and are ideally suited to take a low-energy bulb.

Each lamp is 20cm x 12cm diameter

About Liz Emtage

Liz Emtage Ceramics make bespoke, translucent, porcelain lighting, hand-built in unrestrained natural forms that exploit the malleable quality of the clay. These lamps are inlaid with different organic textures, which leave a delicate impression in the clay surface. When lit these lamps emit an ethereal glow, converting the surface decoration into textures of light. When off the lamps become sculptural pieces, rich with subtle surface pattern. The lamps are naturally ivory in colour, although they can have stains mixed into the clay body, creating subtle colour tones - which become more dramatic when the piece is illuminated.

Currently the range consists of table and floor lamps, pendant shades, standard lamps, wall lights and night lights. We also do commissions for clients and develop site specific pieces. Often working with architects, interior designers, visual merchandising managers for high end shops, hotels and restaurants. Individuals can request particular leaves or flowers from their gardens to be inlaid into their light, or a favourite pattern or texture.

More than 20 years experience has gone into the making of Liz Emtage’s unique porcelain lighting. A passion for art and design that has developed over a lifetime. Liz is inspired by the power and the beauty of the natural world. She constantly experiments with the clay in order to expand the range of lights and finishes that can be produced.

Delivery

While delivery will usually be within 2-5 days, because all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists/designers, delivery may take up to six weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

name: Kathy Dalwood: Aviatrix
description:
Height 29cm

About Kathy Dalwood

The plaster bust collection

Contemporary re-interpretations of the 18th and 19th century portrait bust, these plaster busts are direct casts from sculptures which Kathy has created from real-life materials and objects.

Rather than sculpting the cloth, hair and lace as in traditional busts, Kathy made costumes from real materials and then cast from these, the plaster picking up all the textured detail of the original.

As the collection has developed Kathy started to look closely at historical head dress and her research led her to the intriguing 18th century fad of decorating hats with very large scale, incongruous objects - famously Marie Antoinette adorned a hat with a huge ship in full sail. She introduced the idea in this sculpture collection, placing architectural monuments, iconic landmarks along with random objects on the hats and costumes.

Delivery


As all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists and designers, delivery may take up to six weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

name: Madeleine Boulesteix: Duet Teacup Chandelier
description:
Deluxe Duet tea cup chandelier - candle only

Assorted antiquities 32 x 50cm 2012

About Madeleine Boulesteix

Madeleine started making chandeliers after finding about 40 faceted glass drops in a pile of rubbish. Initially she resisted the temptation to make a chandelier because that would be too obvious, however, she later succumbed and has been making them ever since.

When she started to gather other things to make a structure with, she discovered that everything she needed was right there just waiting to be assembled; glass teacups, trifle moulds, tea strainers etc all for the taking. She'd never used a pastry cutter for pastry or a toast rack for toast but they seemed to have more potential, so she liberated them from their domestic duties by incorporating them in her chandeliers.

Madeleine prefers to work with things she's found and let their qualities dictate what happens. Each piece is unique and begins with a really simple set of ideas, a shape, a colour combination and the objects she wants to use.

The Jelly bowl lanterns are a recent development to complement the Teacup chandeliers. She wanted to make a pendant light that would house a low energy bulb.

Madeleine has exhibited in Denmark, Belgium, Switzerland and Japan as well as the UK.

The British Council have a large piece in their collection, which toured in Australia, India and Egypt and is now installed in their residences in Cairo.

Due to the bespoke nature of Madeleine's chandeliers they are priced individually. Madeleine will undertake commissions larger than regular domestic sizes, for bars and shops, past clients have included Bar Room Bar for 10 venues, Laura Ashley, Harrods and Triskel Arts in Cork for European City of Culture 2005.

name: Daniel Reynolds: Large Stoneware Vessels
description:
Large hand-built pots between 45 and 60 cm high the price of £550 refers to each vessel.

About Daniel Reynolds 
Daniel explores the dichotomy between the traditional and contemporary and the natural and synthetic in his beautiful hand-built porcelain and stoneware work.

He recreates both organic and man-made forms using hand-built moulds to create stunningly natural, organically shaped forms. More recently, Daniel has been working on these series of hand built pots in various sizes and glazes.

Daniel has had number of solo shows and is an internationally acclaimed ceramicist, having shown his work in Spain, Venezuela, Sweden and the UK.

Delivery

As all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists and designers, delivery may take up to six weeks if they are not in stock. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

name: Jim Jack: Untitled sculpture
description:
Plywood, 156 x 36 x 36cm 

About Jim Jack

Jim Jack produces beautifully crafted, layered, wooden sculptures. Jim meticulously constructs each of his sculptures laminating, gluing and dowling each layer of wood, which he pre-cuts, finishes and carves down with rasps files and a grinder. His forms are influenced mostly by nature and are concerned with growth and movement. Jim's work is very labour intensive sometimes taking up to three months to make. He works from exploratory drawings, colour, sketches and etchings and often works on more than one piece at once, each one influencing the other in some way - sculptures making sculpture. Like nature itself, Jim's sculptures are objects of great beauty. In a room they command huge presence and it is hard to resist touching them and handling the seductive curved tactile forms. Jim Jack has been sculpting for more than twenty-five years and has had group and solo shows nationally. 

Delivery

We work with specialist art handlers to deliver our heavier sculptures, paintings and wall work. Please contact us debra@cavalierofinn.com with your address if you would like to purchase this sculpture and we will confirm expected delivery date and costs once your email has been received.

name: Kate Noble - The Jubilee Wave
description:
The Jubilee Wave - oil on aluminum, 120 x 100cm, 2012

About Kate Noble

Kate Noble is an artist living and working in the West Country. Her current work, a series of paintings which explore the area between figuration and abstraction. Images are ‘stolen’ using her mobile phone in public areas A narrative emerges in Kate's mind from these 'stolen' images. Often after Kate has painted the initial figurative image in oil on linen, a photograph is pasted on a board of the same size, abstracting from the replica to arrive at the essence of the image by simplifying the elements, using mixed media and resin, and simultaneously working further on the original work.

Kate uses many creative platforms in her work including animation, film, paints, photography and textiles.

Kate studied fine art at the Ruskin School in Oxford and at the Florence Academy of Art. She is currently doing research at the University of the West of England, investigating the relevance of contemporary traditional portraiture, and its place in today’s art world.

Delivery

We work with specialist art handlers to deliver our paintings and wall work. We will confirm expected delivery date and costs once your order has been received

name: Custhom - Goldsmiths Quilt
description:
The Goldsmiths quilts are manufactured in England. The CUSTHOM Goldsmiths embroidered design is stitched using Maderia threads onto 100% Jersey for amazing comfort.

150cm x 200cm

100% jersey – Goldsmiths quilt cover

About Custhom

About Jemma Ooi and Nathan Philpott - Custhom

Design collective CUSTHOM (Nathan Philpott and Jemma Ooi) began their collaboration shortly after graduating from the Royal College of Art in 2007. They have researched and developed user interactive products with the aim to explore processes and challenge the mass production of todays products.

Their work focuses on silk screen printing & digital embroidery in the aim to push ideas of aesthetic as a reaction to the present. The possibilities of these processes have been manipulated and experimented with, informing the development and diversity of their work. 
All their wallpapers are printed using water based inks in the UK, and mostly in places just on their doorstep, so they can have a really close working relationship with their manufacturers and keep the quality and uniqueness of their work the priority when designing.

"Our designs have always had a core theme of individuality or change of state - allowing uniqueness and unexpected outcomes. Yet we feel the roll of the designer is not to provide an open ended result but to have considered all possibilities allowing the product to properly function and work aesthetically." - CUSTHOM

Delivery

While delivery will usually be within 2-5 days, because all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists/designers, delivery may take up to six weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

name: Ali Miller - More Tea Range
description:
Whimsical skeletal design created in response to Ali's exploration of the cycle of life and death

Product Info: 100% cotton with tag for hanging. Dimensions: approximately 70 cm long by 50 cm wide Machine washable: Cool wash 30C Made in the UK

About Ali Miller

Ali Miller grew up in London and completed her Art Foundation at Camberwell College of Art before going on to Brighton University where she gained a BA (Hons) degree in Fine Art/Sculpture in 2003.

Ali Miller has exhibited widely since graduating, with recent exhibitions and art fairs in London, New York, Chicago, Miami and Paris. Exhibitions include Brave Soldier and Black Butterfly; a solo exhibition at Liberty of London and an exhibition at Skylark, the artist-run gallery at the Oxo Tower on London’s South Bank.

Achievements include a tea set for the Liverpool Tate to support their Alice in Wonderland exhibition, a tea set collection she created for Paul Smith, and a greeting card collection for Liberty of London. Her work has appeared in Company magazine, The Independent on Sunday and Elle Decoration to name but a few.

Ali's work is fundamentally an amalgamation of personal experiences, family history, religion and identity and also the relationship between the individual to the material.

Memory for Ali is a source of euphoric inspiration and, whilst her work might signify a nostalgic reminiscence of years past, it also carries with it the weight of pressures and experience of real life. It is the memories that Ali believes shapes her life and art, first and foremost.

She presents these to the viewer as an aesthetic composition enriched by the use of different textures, material and patterns: the artworks created are an expression of Ali’s design perspective and interest in family history - an unusual combination, but one that succeeds in creating artwork of remarkable intimacy and harmonious composition.

Delivery

name: Kathy Dalwood: Galileo Plaster Bust
description:
This bust is named after Galileo the Italian scientist who in 1589  dropped two balls of different masses from the Leaning Tower of Pisa to demonstrate that their time of descent was independent of their mass. Height 30cm including the plinth

Available in white or grey plaster

About Kathy Dalwood

The plaster bust collection

Contemporary re-interpretations of the 18th and 19th century portrait bust, these plaster busts are direct casts from sculptures which Kathy has created from real-life materials and objects.

Rather than sculpting the cloth, hair and lace as in traditional busts, Kathy made costumes from real materials and then cast from these, the plaster picking up all the textured detail of the original.

As the collection has developed Kathy started to look closely at historical head dress and her research led her to the intriguing 18th century fad of decorating hats with very large scale, incongruous objects - famously Marie Antoinette adorned a hat with a huge ship in full sail. She introduced the idea in this sculpture collection, placing architectural monuments, iconic landmarks along with random objects on the hats and costumes.

Delivery


As all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists and designers, delivery may take up to six weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

The plaster bust collection

Contemporary re-interpretations of the 18th and 19th century portrait bust, these plaster busts are direct casts from sculptures which Kathy has created from real-life materials and objects.

Rather than sculpting the cloth, hair and lace as in traditional busts, Kathy made costumes from real materials and then cast from these, the plaster picking up all the textured detail of the original.

As the collection has developed Kathy started to look closely at historical head dress and her research led her to the intriguing 18th century fad of decorating hats with very large scale, incongruous objects - famously Marie Antoinette adorned a hat with a huge ship in full sail. She introduced the idea in this sculpture collection, placing architectural monuments, iconic landmarks along with random objects on the hats and costumes.

The busts are available in white or grey plaster.

name: Richard Brendon: Reflect tea cup & saucer
description:
Reflect brings life back to antique saucers missing their other halves by using platinum gilding to create a highly reflective teacup. The mirrored cups reflect the patterned saucers, uniting them as a perfect couples.  

Made in Stoke-on-Trent, the bone china cups are hand painted with platinum and then paired with orphan saucers, which are meticulously selected from antique dealers across Britain.

The range of antique saucers date from 1870-1930 (with the odd gem from the 50s occasionally too).  Richard has also sourced some rather rare saucers pre-1850.  To qualify as rare they must be produced by a prestigious factory and be very beautiful. 

As all saucers are unique and individually sourced, it is not possible to choose a certain design currently.  If you give us an idea of the colourway you would like we will do our best to match it when selecting your saucer.

-Fine bone china with platinum gilding
-Made in Stoke-on-Trent, England
-Handwash only


Comes in a specially designed gift box.

About Richard Brendon

Richard is a London based designer. He studied Product and Furniture design at Kingston University. He has a particular interest in reusing existing objects and investigating the properties of materials. The recurring theme in his work is to design objects with longevity because he believes this to be the best way to ensure sustainability.

Delivery

While delivery will usually be within 2-5 days, because all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists/designers, delivery may take up to six weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

description:

name: Sam Edkins: Anatomically Correct Chair Heart
description:
The Anatomically Correct Chair

In these works the designer-maker Sam Edkins makes reference to Memento Mori, a theme often depicted in art and classical antiquity. 

Sam uses imagery sourced from old medical journals which he tailors to suit each antique chair before digitally printing his design on to brushed velvet. As a process this allows Sam to embroider a new history into them and makes each one slightly different. The shape of the chair allows the print to flow into the chair structure, giving a figurative character and seeming to personify the piece.  

Each chair is fully reconditioned and upholstered by Sam with his design.  

About Sam Edkins

Sam Edkins is a London based artist/designer living and working in London.

He studied Fine Art at Goldsmiths College. Sam's work is a combination of the sculptural and the practical.  By working with antique pieces, Sam successfully marries the old with the new, creating something altogether contemporary and bespoke. His work combines traditional craft and technology. 

Taking inspiration from the cabinet of curiosity, museums and personal collections alike, Sam uses them as a source of reference, visually, conceptually and historically. Containing a degree of nostalgia all of his work harks back to a time when knowledge was craved and a desire to understand the world was paramount.

Delivery
-------------------------------------------------------
We have this and a number of other anatomically correct chairs in stock in various designs. Please contact us to for a full list of the works available.     There will be an additional delivery charge for the chairs which will we confirm once your order has been placed.

name: Curiousa & Curiousa: Small Hand Blown Glass Pendants
description:
Single glass shades, hand blown to order, with four shapes available and a choice of four colours. Lights include 1m fabric twisted flex and metal fittings. Colours from back to front of the main picture - Purple, Smoked Olive, Sky Blue and Yellow Ochre. 

Other colours available upon request.  Extra flex over 1m length available at £8 p/m please contact us for this option. Glass samples available on request.

All the glass lighting has been designed by Esther Patterson and made in England. Each piece is unique and individually hand-blown. Any small imperfections are part of the making process. 

About Esther Patterson of Curiousa & Curiousa
---------------------------------------------------------

Esther Patterson, the founder of Curiousa & Curiousa designs hand-blown, bespoke glass and bone china lighting solutions and fabric designs for use in furnishing and wall coverings. 

The glass pendant range offers a wide choice of colour, shape and size providing shades from 130mm to 330mm in diameter. Each shade is traditionally free blown without moulds, allowing virtually any shape, size and colour to be achieved.  If you have a specific colour or shape request please do contact us.

Based in the Midlands with a commitment to working with UK based craftspeople and suppliers. Esther continues to work locally with carpenters, fabricators, photographers and glass blowers. All highly skilled crafts people.

Esther launched her range at Tent in 2010. The glass pendants were selected for 'Elle Decoration Approval' along with nine other products from the whole show. 

Delivery
-----------------------------------------------------------
As all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists and designers, delivery may take up to six or this case eight weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

name: Liz Emtage - Summer grasses tealight or vase
description:
Each vessel is 13cm x 10cm diameter

'Summer grasses tealight-vase' a versatile translucent bone china vessel that can be used as either a tea light holder or a vase. Inspired by Liz's happy childhood memories of relaxing in meadows on hot summer afternoons.

Slip cast in the UK, in Bone China. Each one is slightly different in form, because of the way the clay moves in the kiln. 

About Liz Emtage

Liz Emtage Ceramics make bespoke, translucent, porcelain lighting, hand-built in unrestrained natural forms that exploit the malleable quality of the clay. These lamps are inlaid with different organic textures, which leave a delicate impression in the clay surface. When lit these lamps emit an ethereal glow, converting the surface decoration into textures of light. When off the lamps become sculptural pieces, rich with subtle surface pattern. The lamps are naturally ivory in colour, although they can have stains mixed into the clay body, creating subtle colour tones - which become more dramatic when the piece is illuminated. 

Currently the range consists of table and floor lamps, pendant shades, standard lamps, wall lights and night lights. We also do commissions for clients and develop site specific pieces. Often working with architects, interior designers, visual merchandising managers for high end shops, hotels and restaurants. Individuals can request particular leaves or flowers from their gardens to be inlaid into their light, or a favourite pattern or texture. 

More than 20 years experience has gone into the making of Liz Emtage’s unique porcelain lighting. A passion for art and design that has developed over a lifetime. Liz is inspired by the power and the beauty of the natural world. She constantly experiments with the clay in order to expand the range of lights and finishes that can be produced.  

Delivery

While delivery will usually be within 2-5 days, because all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists/designers, delivery may take up to six weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

name: Michelle McKinney: Journey 2
description:
Triptych, hand-sculpted swallowtail butterflies made from stainless steel, framed in perspex boxes, each perspex box is 650mmx250mm.

About Michelle McKinney

Michelle Mckinney’s art is work of elegant simplicity which, in itself, is the first of many seductions into an engagement with a complex network of tensions. The work is bedded in the clear space between opposites; the movement captured in stillness; the fragility and ephemerality of nature captured in the strength and permanence of industrial, man made materials; inexorable freedom within the clinically defined limitations of space. It is the dialogue that takes place between these polarities that engage so forcefully.
 
Whilst utilising symbols found in nature that have a timeless constancy, the methods and materials used are innovative applications of contemporary industrial products subtly handled so that even the closest scrutiny of the materials give almost no intimation of their origins. This play between the timeless and the immediate is at the heart of Michelle’s work. However tranquil the order of the instant may seem it cannot segregate itself from the underlying chaos of nature and it is into this engagement with chaos that we are lured, so unassumingly, by the captivating simplicity of order.

Delivery

We work with specialist art handlers to deliver our paintings and wall work. We will confirm expected delivery date and costs once your order has been received, if you are unhappy with the delivery and costs upon receipt of this confirmation, your order can be cancelled and a full refund will be issued.

name: Rowena Brown: raku fired house 1
description:
Stoneware houses group of four, height from 9-13cm tall

About Rowena Brown

Rowena’s inspiration comes from media images showing the aftermath of environmental and manmade disruption, and also from weather-worn and derelict structures in the Scottish landscape.

Her handmade ceramic buildings are distinguished by their individual surface texture, marks and features. The forms are part-glazed, then raku or stoneware fired. Each of the pieces has its own character. They can be seen as isolated forms, or as part of a group evoking human interaction and community.

Rowena has a BA in Fashion Design from St. Martins School of Art in London, an MA in Fine Art from the University of Leeds and has exhibited work in California, Yorkshire and London. \

Delivery

name: Kate Noble: The Jubilee Line
description:
oil on aluminum 100x120cm

About Kate Noble

Kate Noble is an artist living and working in the West Country. Her current work, a series of paintings which explore the area between figuration and abstraction. Images are ‘stolen’ using her mobile phone in public areas A narrative emerges in Kate's mind from these 'stolen' images. Often after Kate has painted the initial figurative image in oil on linen, a photograph is pasted on a board of the same size, abstracting from the replica to arrive at the essence of the image by simplifying the elements, using mixed media and resin, and simultaneously working further on the original work.

Kate uses many creative platforms in her work including animation, film, paints, photography and textiles.

Kate studied fine art at the Ruskin School in Oxford and at the Florence Academy of Art. She is currently doing research at the University of the West of England, investigating the relevance of contemporary traditional portraiture, and its place in today’s art world.

Delivery

We work with specialist art handlers to deliver our paintings and wall work. We will confirm expected delivery date and costs once your order has been received.

name: Trevor Burgess: A Place to Live 13
description:
A Place to Live 13
Oil on plywood
34 x 41cm


About Trevor Burgess

Recent regional prize winner of the The Discerning Eye, most of Trevor's work is about the ordinary business of living. Trevor is interested in a painting that explores relationships, people, contemporary urban spaces.

Although people tend to be the focus of attention, he is also concerned with the context of social interaction. There are recurring themes in the pictures which fascinate him, such as the interplay of signs within the cityscape, or how urban architecture creates a visually distinctive micro-environment at street level, and how momentary appearances are registered, glimpsed or over-looked in passing by.

Trevor’s work developed over a period of time when he was exploring the use of a less literally descriptive, painterly, figurative language in a series of paintings on the theme of the family, which culminated in some large works done on the MA Fine Art course in Barcelona in 1997/8. After this Trevor moved to London, and felt the need for a more concrete subject and specificity for his work. He turned to the immediate urban environment, and began using his own photographs as source material.

Trevor does not attempt to replicate the conventions of photography. In all representational art there is a gap between what is depicted and how it’s depicted. The peculiar pleasures of painting, for him, are all about this gap.

He uses a glossy liquid paint which brings out the flashes of bright colour that animate urban space. The fluidity, coarseness and texture of the paint contribute to a sense of the thickening of the air in the urban atmosphere, the ambiguity and the discontinuity of visual experience.

The recent series, "A Place to Live" draws on property adverts in newspapers. These paintings use thin glazes directly onto plywood, which absorbs the colour.

Delivery

About Daniel Reynolds
Daniel explores the dichotomy between the traditional and contemporary and the natural and synthetic in his beautiful hand-built porcelain and stoneware work.

He recreates both organic and man-made forms using hand-built moulds to create stunningly natural, organically shaped forms.  More recently, Daniel has been working on these series of hand built pots in various sizes and glazes.

Daniel has had number of solo shows and is an internationally acclaimed ceramicist, having shown his work in Spain, Venezuela, Sweden and the UK.

name: Melanie Porter: Knitted covered swivel chair: Harry
description:
Harry is an original 1960’s swivel chair on a metal base with wood finish. Covered in a handknitted highly textured patchwork design, with contrast colour deep-set crocheted buttons.

Cover – 100% Merino wool | H-100cm, D-80cm, W-75cm

About Melanie Porter

After 10 years working as a knitwear designer for a number of international fashion brands, Melanie turned her expertise to furniture, creating one-off contemporary designs from chairs sourced from auctions and markets across the UK.

Each project starts with the chair itself – anything from an antique Victorian nursing chair, to a 1970s Egg chair – which is painstakingly stripped back to the frame, before being restored and reupholstered using traditional techniques. This blank canvas is then covered with a series of hand-knitted panels, especially created for each chair.

Melanie undertakes the entire process herself and everything, from the restoration and upholstering to the individual, crocheted buttons, is done by hand. The result of this incredibly labour-intensive process is a stunning and unique work of art, destined to be a future family heirloom.

Delivery

As all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists and designers, delivery may take up to six weeks or in this case, 10 weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

name: Kaori Tatebayashi: Black and white Hyacinths
description:
Black and white Hyacinth, hand built stoneware, 6.5" x 2.5" Priced individually.

About Kaori Tatebayashi

When Kaori was little, her family moved from one place to another due to her parents' work. Every time she had to adjust and familiarise herself with a new home, school and friends. Sometimes a box or two of her stuff went missing during the move and she would lose a whole lot of things suddenly. All this meant that she become increasingly unattached to objects. She found that it was her recollection of childhood which became more palpable and concrete instead.

Her memories often do not involve particularly significant events.  Many of them are featureless everyday observations like remembering the pattern of a stone pavement on her way to school or the silhouette of a light bulb hanging from the ceiling of her grandmother's house. She still feels an acute affinity with these small scenes. She unwraps them slowly in her mind and inhabits, even smells them.

Kaori uses clay as a device to make fragments of time visible. She wants to preserve the intimate and transient recollections of our lives and seal them in the clay like a fern petrified into a fossil. Firing changes soft, malleable clay into hard, breakable ceramic. As clay loses its organic life in the firing, it allows time to become encased. The nature of fired clay incorporates both fragility and permanence and it is this which enables the material to record elusive things like memory.

Kaori traces everyday objects in clay like an old pair of shoes, a girls camisole or a discarded box of buttons - the sort of bits and pieces you might have owned once but forgotten all about. Through looking at her work, you are led back into those tiny, quiet recesses of your past.

Born in Arita, a small village in Japan renowned for its fine porcelain, Kaori Tatebayashi grew up in a family who traded in pottery. She studied ceramics at Kyoto City University of Art for a Bachelors and Masters in ceramics during 1991-97. During the initial year of her Masters degree she became London's Scholarship ceramic student at the Royal College of Art, and in 1999 participated in Japan's 6th Ceramic Biennale. In 2006, Kaori won the Crafts Council Development Award and set up her workshop at 4011⁄4 Studios in Wandsworth, London. She has widely exhibited throughout the UK and Japan and her exhibitions include, two years at Chelsea's Craft Fair - winning the Design for Scandinavian Award in 2004, three years at Origin, London (2006-08) and has exhibited for two years at Ceramic Art, London (2005 & 07).

name: Kate Wickham - ceramic vessels
description:
Ceramic vessel, white stoneware, approximate 48cm high

Originally from Sheffield, Yorkshire, Kate trained at Camberwell College of Art and the Royal College of Art in London, and now lives and works in Sussex.

Kate makes hand built painterly vessel forms exploring a number of ideas and themes – landscapes, domestic interiors, seascapes etc. – through abstraction and symbolism, and through the use of colour, texture, mark making and gestural drawing. Both drawing and painting inform the work and all pieces are one off or small limited editions. Each of Kate's vessels is hand built using slabs of white stoneware clay. The clay surfaces are drawn onto and incised into both before and after she builds them. Layers of colour are then built up using slips, oxides, body stains, underglaze colours and glazes. Kate then fires the work to about 1120 degree C.

Kate's work is in both private and public collections in Britain and abroad, including the Crafts Council collection and South East Arts.

She is the founder and head of the Ceramics Diploma course at City Lit College in central London.

name: Sophie Cook - selection
description:
These subtle, sculptural ceramic pieces with their vibrant glazes lift any room.  Please note that once you have bought one, you'll soon want another!  They are a collector's dream.

Featured here from the back row and then eft to right are:
Tall bottle matt olive 
Big bottle matt light grey 
Medium teardrop vessel shiny white 
Small short neck bottle matt graphite
Medium pod matt white
Small pod matt aubergine
 



About Sophie Cook

Sophie graduated from Camberwell School of Arts in 1997. Since then her work has grown from strength to strength and is now featured in permanent museum collections ranging from the Geoffrye Museum in London to recently involvment in the Denver Art Museum's Euro Design exhibition. Georgio Armani and Elton John are even known collectors of her work!

Sophie also works on commissions, which have included pieces for Babington House and an installation for the Rama Restaurant in the private members club, 50 st james.

Currently throwing porcelain bottles and pods on the wheel, Sophie's vibrant glazes embody subtle, sculptural shapes to create fluid, ethereal forms. Her inspiration originally came from an urge to react against much of the traditional ceramic pieces she had seen, whose glazes seemed dark and murky. She wanted to create pieces where colour embodied the pot, rather than being surface decoration. She looked to towers and sky-high buildings for her inspiration initially but essence of form and simplicity are now the main factors.

Her new work features fluid abstract lines which are transformed into a landscape by adding graphic architectural figures and trees.

The making of Sophie's bottles and pods is quite complicated. Each of Sophie's bottles or pods are thrown on the wheel. They are then left to dry overnight and then carved by hand to give extra definition to their shape. It is an incredibly delicate process and at any point the piece can crack. Each piece is then fired in the kiln and the glaze is applied by a spraying technique. The glazes are original and have taken several years of testing to fine tune.

The pieces are then further fired to 1260’C. During the firing there are further risks due to the fragility of the porcelain and the heat of the kiln. On average, during the entire making process, only fifty per cent of the pieces will survive.

Delivery

While delivery will usually be within 2-5 days, because all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists/designers, delivery may take up to six weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

name: Madeleine Boulesteix - chandeliers for commission
description:
Examples of Madeleine's work, please contact us for current prices and availability. Commissions undertaken, may take up to 12 weeks. Prices start from approximately £350 plus delivery for a duet chandeliers up to £950 for a large 8 cup teacup chandelier not featured below but possible to commission.

Images of work featured
Electric quartet cup chandelier, single central bulb, golf ball size - max 60 watts.
Use of candles is NOT recommended simultaneously as they create too much heat. 32/36cm wide x 60/70cm long. 

6 cup chandelier, single central bulb gulf ball size. max 60 watts. Use of candles is NOT recommended simultaneously as they create too much heat. 32/36cm wide x 60/70cm long. 

Opal raspberry chandelier for candles -  4 cups for candles only - in glass pots supplied.
32/36cm wide x 60/70cm long. 

Green Quartet chandelier for candles - 4 cups for candles in glass pots supplied.
32/36cm wide x 60/70cm long. 

Chinoiserie Duet chandelier for candles You cannot commission these, but please contact us to see if we have available in this size - 3 candles only, 32cm wide x 50cm long. 

Not featured but available - 8 cup chandelier, 4 bulbs (clear candle twist 25 watts), nightlight candles can go in the teacups too in special glass pots (supplied). 60cm wide x 70cm long. Shorter ones can be made for low ceilings - min 55cm.


About Madeleine Boulesteix

Madeleine started making chandeliers after finding about 40 faceted glass drops in a pile of rubbish. Initially she resisted the temptation to make a chandelier because that would be too obvious, however, she later succumbed and has been making them ever since.

When she started to gather other things to make a structure with, she discovered that everything she needed was right there just waiting to be assembled; glass teacups, trifle moulds, tea strainers etc all for the taking.  She'd never used a pastry cutter for pastry or a toast rack for toast but they seemed to have more potential, so she liberated them from their domestic duties by incorporating them in her chandeliers.

Madeleine prefers to work with things she's found and let their qualities dictate what happens. Each piece is unique and begins with a really simple set of ideas, a shape, a colour combination and the objects she wants to use.

The Jelly bowl lanterns are a recent development to complement the Teacup chandeliers. She wanted to make a pendant light that would house a low energy bulb.

Madeleine has exhibited in Denmark, Belgium, Switzerland and Japan as well as the UK.

The British Council have a large piece in their collection, which toured in Australia, India and Egypt and is now installed in their residences in Cairo.

Due to the bespoke nature of Madeleine's chandeliers they are priced individually.  Madeleine will undertake commissions larger than regular domestic sizes, for bars and shops, past clients have included Bar Room Bar for 10 venues, Laura Ashley, Harrods and Triskel Arts in Cork for European City of Culture 2005.

name: Furniture Magpies - Lovely Legs Lights
description:
Lovely Legs lights - made from upcycled furniture 

Lampshade made from recycled wool, base of the lamp made from recycled chair legs

About Furniture Magpies

Furniture Magpies is a furniture ‘design and make’ company offering an alternative to mass-produced products and specialising in regenerating old furniture to meet the requirements of the modern consumer. It creates one-off and limited edition pieces, breathing new life into otherwise unwanted items.

“In our work we strive to retain the character and story of the furniture that we use, affording the user an insight into their item’s original identity. We don’t believe in good furniture going to landfill when it can be redesigned into a piece that people can love all over again.”

Furniture Magpies is made up of a small team of designer-makers headed by directors Nessa Doran O’Reilly, Sivan Metzer and Sua Lee. Located in a town once famed for being the centre of the British furniture manufacturing industry, Furniture Magpies is perfectly poised to capitalise on a rich supply of pieces that retain quality of construction and make use of materials which are seldom found in today’s mass-produced furniture; pieces that have for one reason or another, been discarded. The company then focuses on breathing new life into these disused items by not only improving them aesthetically but also considering how they could function more effectively in today’s domestic environment. By combining these old components with new and vintage fabrics, as well as using some traditional techniques such as deep button upholstery, they create pieces with a distinctive and contemporary twist.

 

“Our company explores the extensive possibilities of creating unique, yet functional pieces through the process of upcycling discarded furniture.”

“Our designs are a little bit like a recipe, we always use the same ingredients but each piece comes out a little different every time.”


Due to the nature of reusing existing furniture and reclaimed materials, consumers can be confident that each piece is entirely individual and sold as a unique item.

Delivery

While delivery will usually be within 2-5 days, because all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists/designers, delivery may take up to six weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

name: Matthew Chambers - various works
description:
Examples of Matthew's work, please contact us for current prices and availability. Commissions undertaken, may take up to 12 weeks. Prices start from £900 plus delivery

Images of work featured
* Ensphere - Clique series 2010. 32cm H
* Sun - Clique series 2011. 33cm H
* Colours4 - 1 Face series 2011. 17.5cm H (each)
* Spiral (cream) - Clique series 2011. 39cm H
* Twist - 1 Face series 2006. 30cm H


About Matthew Chambers

Matthew's influences and inspirations for his beautiful circular sculptures include - geometric and optical art, constructivist themes, and modern architecture and design. He pursues these interests in an abstract sense by exploring shape and making mathematically constructed pieces in clay, each built up of many different wheel-thrown sections. On completion each form conveys different and individual properties of space, light, and colour, and sustains an expression of abstract and rhythmical beauty from its pattern of shape.

Matthew's sculptures are made using either an earthenware or stoneware clay, with colours added directly into the body. When each form has been constructed, several weeks are allowed for slow drying to minimise shrinkage and warping problems. Once dry the piece is sculpted to achieve a finer shape and then low fired.  It is sanded and then high fired again.  Once fully fired each piece is polished once again, this time with diamond abrasives to help achieve a very smooth overall finish.

Matthew studied his MA at the Royal College of Art. He was also winner of the Poole Pottery award for Ceramic Shape.

name: Alice Mara - Hanging People Cups and Saucer
description:
Cup 8.5x6.5cm Saucer 12cm diameter Bone china, made in UK

About Alice Mara

Alice's interest in clay started at the early age of eight at a Saturday morning kid’s club. She went on to do her degree in workshop ceramics at Harrow College and later embarked on a Masters at the Royal College of Art.

The main inspiration for Alice's work is her local environment and the everyday, mundane experiences that occur within it. She walks around armed with her camera ready to catalogue these experiences so that she can incorporate them into her work.

She uses vivid imagery to create an almost utopian sense of place.

Alice's work has been shown at a prestigious exhibition held at Canary Wharfs' Canada Square foyer with nine other ceramic/glass artists. Alice also won the Queensbury Hunt award for most innovative use of ceramic material.

description:
Home Sweet Home bone china tea set as featured in the BBC's acclaimed Sherlock Holmes series. This 18ct gold edged tea set is printed with a map of the British isles accented with old world sailing ships and playful red crowns.  Designs that blends classic British imagery together to create a new contemporary style. 

Product Info : Fine Bone china, 24 carat gold details
Tea pot: Tea for 4 cups
Cup and saucer: Fine Bone china, 24 carat gold details
Dimensions of Tea cup approximately: 8.5cm at widest point and 11.5cm with handle by 7.5cm height.
Dimensions saucer approximately: 14.5cm in diameter 
Cake plate: Dimensions approximately: 21.5cm in diameter

We would recommend that these pieces be hand washed only.
Made, applied and designed in the UK

About Ali Miller

Ali Miller grew up in London and completed her Art Foundation at Camberwell College of Art before going on to Brighton University where she gained a BA (Hons) degree in Fine Art/Sculpture in 2003.

Ali Miller has exhibited widely since graduating, with recent exhibitions and art fairs in London, New York, Chicago, Miami and Paris. Exhibitions include Brave Soldier and Black Butterfly; a solo exhibition at Liberty of London and an exhibition at Skylark, the artist-run gallery at the Oxo Tower on London’s South Bank. 

Achievements include a tea set for the Liverpool Tate to support their Alice in Wonderland exhibition, a tea set collection she created for Paul Smith, and a greeting card collection for Liberty of London. Her work has appeared in Company magazine, The Independent on Sunday and Elle Decoration to name but a few.

Ali's work is fundamentally an amalgamation of personal experiences, family history, religion and identity and also the relationship between the individual to the material.

Memory for Ali is a source of euphoric inspiration and, whilst her work might signify a nostalgic reminiscence of years past, it also carries with it the weight of pressures and experience of real life. It is the memories that Ali believes shapes her life and art, first and foremost.

She presents these to the viewer as an aesthetic composition enriched by the use of different textures, material and patterns: the artworks created are an expression of Ali’s design perspective and interest in family history - an unusual combination, but one that succeeds in creating artwork of remarkable intimacy and harmonious composition.

Delivery

We have this range in stock.

name: Custhom - Hand foiled Columbia Road Wallpaper
description:
Hand foiled wallpaper sold per metre (maximum length 10m non repeating image) 50cm wide

Also available in Pewter and Matt Gold foil, if you'd like to order these please specify on your order, all are made to order and create an amazing texture over a darker background which reflects delicately in the light.

This paper also looks great in a wooden box frame 1.5m long propped up against your wall. Please contact us for more information about these.

About Jemma Ooi and Nathan Philpott - Custhom

Design collective CUSTHOM (Nathan Philpott and Jemma Ooi) began their collaboration shortly after graduating from the Royal College of Art in 2007. They have researched and developed user interactive products with the aim to explore processes and challenge the mass production of todays products.


Their work focuses on silk screen printing & digital embroidery in the aim to push ideas of aesthetic as a reaction to the present. The possibilities of these processes have been manipulated and experimented with, informing the development and diversity of their work.
All their wallpapers are printed using water based inks in the UK, and mostly in places just on their doorstep, so they can have a really close working relationship with their manufacturers and keep the quality and uniqueness of their work the priority when designing.

"Our designs have always had a core theme of individuality or change of state - allowing uniqueness and unexpected outcomes. Yet we feel the roll of the designer is not to provide an open ended result but to have considered all possibilities allowing the product to properly function and work aesthetically." - CUSTHOM

Delivery

While delivery will usually be within 2-5 days, because all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists/designers, delivery may take up to six weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

name: Liz Emtage - summer grass tealight or vase
description:
Each vessel is 13cm x 10cm diameter

'Summer grasses tealight-vase' a versatile translucent bone china vessel that can be used as either a tea light holder or a vase. Inspired by Liz's happy childhood memories of relaxing in meadows on hot summer afternoons.

Slip cast in the UK, in Bone China. Each one is slightly different in form, because of the way the clay moves in the kiln. 

About Liz Emtage

Liz Emtage Ceramics make bespoke, translucent, porcelain lighting, hand-built in unrestrained natural forms that exploit the malleable quality of the clay. These lamps are inlaid with different organic textures, which leave a delicate impression in the clay surface. When lit these lamps emit an ethereal glow, converting the surface decoration into textures of light. When off the lamps become sculptural pieces, rich with subtle surface pattern. The lamps are naturally ivory in colour, although they can have stains mixed into the clay body, creating subtle colour tones - which become more dramatic when the piece is illuminated. 

Currently the range consists of table and floor lamps, pendant shades, standard lamps, wall lights and night lights. We also do commissions for clients and develop site specific pieces. Often working with architects, interior designers, visual merchandising managers for high end shops, hotels and restaurants. Individuals can request particular leaves or flowers from their gardens to be inlaid into their light, or a favourite pattern or texture. 

More than 20 years experience has gone into the making of Liz Emtage’s unique porcelain lighting. A passion for art and design that has developed over a lifetime. Liz is inspired by the power and the beauty of the natural world. She constantly experiments with the clay in order to expand the range of lights and finishes that can be produced.  

Delivery

While delivery will usually be within 2-5 days, because all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists/designers, delivery may take up to six weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

name: Mizuyo Yamashita - flora bowls
description:
Flora wobbly bowl, porcelain. 120mm diameter £32.00

Flora tiny wobbly bowl, porcelain. 80mm diameter £16.00

Flora tiny tiny wobbly bowl, porcelain. 50mm diameter £10.00

About Mizuyo Yamashita

Mizuyo Yamashita's delicate porcelain ceramics are inspired from nature, the material and the process.

Living in an era of mass-production and waste, there is feeling that everything is replaceable. Mizuyo's response to this is to make fragile porcelain pieces that reach out to people and make them want to protect them.

Each of her bowls is hand-shaped and, like flowers, leaves, animals and human beings, each one is unique. The bowls are made thin so that one can feel the sense of fragility when picked up.

The images Mizuyo selects to decorate the bowls, butterflies and flowers, reflect this sense of transience with their short lives. So too does her choice of material, preferring to work with porcelain which she uses for its whiteness, fineness, softness (when wet) and sensitivity.

Mizuyo doesn't specify a function for her work because she wants the owners to decide how to use it. The ceramics work well on their own or as a group.

Mizuyo studied ceramics at Kensington and Chelsea college. 
 
Delivery

While delivery will usually be within 2-5 days, because all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists/designers, delivery may take up to six weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

Achievements include a tea set for the Liverpool Tate to support their Alice in Wonderland exhibition, a tea set collection she created for Paul Smith, and a greeting card collection for Liberty of London. Her work has appeared in Company magazine, The Independent on Sunday and Elle Decoration to name but a few.

Ali's work is fundamentally an amalgamation of personal experiences, family history, religion and identity and also the relationship between the individual to the material.

Memory for Ali is a source of euphoric inspiration and, whilst her work might signify a nostalgic reminiscence of years past, it also carries with it the weight of pressures and experience of real life. It is the memories that Ali believes shapes her life and art, first and foremost.

She presents these to the viewer as an aesthetic composition enriched by the use of different textures, material and patterns: the artworks created are an expression of Ali’s design perspective and interest in family history - an unusual combination, but one that succeeds in creating artwork of remarkable intimacy and harmonious composition.

description:

Limited Edition. Made to order.
Delivery 5-8 weeks.

About Esther Patterson of Curiousa & Curiousa
-----------------------------------------------------------

Esther Patterson, the founder of Curiousa & Curiousa designs hand-blown, bespoke glass and bone china lighting solutions and fabric designs for use in furnishing and wall coverings. 

The glass pendant range offers a wide choice of colour, shape and size providing shades from 130mm to 330mm in diameter, complimented with a select range of finishes, fittings, flexes and bulbs. Each shade is traditionally free blown without moulds, allowing virtually any shape, size and colour to be achieved.

Based in the Midlands with a commitment to working with UK based craftspeople and suppliers. Esther continues to work locally with carpenters, fabricators, photographers and glass blowers. All highly skilled crafts people.

Esther launched her range in Design Week at Tent London in 2010 gaining the prestigious 'Elle Decoration Approval' award. With designs used in Harvey Nicols Fifth Floor Cafe and pendants hanging in Jamie Oliver Restaurants, Esther continues to go from strength to strength developing new ranges and bespoke solutions for interior designers, architectural practices and private individuals.

Esther studied at Nottingham Trent University.  

Delivery

As all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists and designers, delivery may take up to six or this case eight weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

name: Alexena Cayless: Open or Wrapped silver chip fork
description:
Alexena has elevated the humble wooden fish and chip fork to a higher level giving it a status and value that reflects Britain’s love of fish and chips. 

The chip forks are cast in solid silver, hall marked and engraved with the question ‘open or wrapped’. The use of silver accentuates the significance bestowed on the object and contrasts the suggestion of fish and chips as a working class meal.

Each fork has been cast and finished by hand by Climal Castings, a company based in the jewellery quarter of Birmingham, famous for its heritage of silversmiths and jewellers.

Open or Wrapped
90L x 10W x 1H mm

About Alexena Cayless

A trained sculptor and furniture designer, Alexena’s work explores the close relationship between art and design. Her work is influenced by memory and the relationship between people and objects.

Alexena’s background is far from conventional, brought up on a Leicestershire farm, she was introduced to art at an early age by her father, also a trained furniture designer. After graduating from a Fine Art degree Alexena became interested in pursuing a career within the social sector, working in art therapy and then as a paramedic. In 2003 Alexena returned to university to study design. Her work is informed by her experiences of working with people, of gathering stories and wanting to retell narratives through objects.
 
Alexena Cayless was Designer in Residence at the Design Museum 2010.  

Delivery

While delivery will usually be within 2-5 days, because all of our items are bespoke and made to order by our artists/designers, delivery may take up to six weeks. We will confirm expected delivery once your order has been received.

A ceramic hip flask with cork stopper, the flasks are cast and glazed by hand in the UK.  82L x 22W x 120H mm

About Alexena Cayless

Alexena Cayless designs furniture and products inspired by human activity and memory. Trained in Fine Art Sculpture and Furniture Design her work explores the close relationship between art and design.

Alexena’s work celebrates traditional British manufacturers and crafts with products ranging from solid silver fish and chip forks to brogue chairs.

All of Alexena’s products are made in the UK.

name: Curiousa & Curiousa: Baby Head Lamp
description:
Hand blown glass shade with sand blasted barbed wire motif. Includes fabric twisted cable and switch. Height: 66cm Width: 18cm.

About Esther Patterson of Curiousa & Curiousa
-----------------------------------------------------------

Esther Patterson, the founder of Curiousa & Curiousa designs hand-blown, bespoke glass and bone china lighting solutions and fabric designs for use in furnishing and wall coverings. 

The glass pendant range offers a wide choice of colour, shape and size providing shades from 130mm to 330mm in diameter, complimented with a select range of finishes, fittings, flexes and bulbs. Each shade is traditionally free blown without moulds, allowing virtually any shape, size and colour to be achieved.

Based in the Midlands with a commitment to working with UK based craftspeople and suppliers. Esther continues to work locally with carpenters, fabricators, photographers and glass blowers. All highly skilled crafts people.

Esther launched her range in Design Week at Tent London in 2010 gaining the prestigious 'Elle Decoration Approval' award. With designs used in Harvey Nicols Fifth Floor Cafe and pendants hanging in Jamie Oliver Restaurants, Esther continues to go from strength to strength developing new ranges and bespoke solutions for interior designers, architectural practices and private individuals.

Esther studied at Nottingham Trent University.

name: Daniel Reynolds: White Pumpkin Bowl
description:
28cm x 18cm slip cast in fine English porcelain. Please allow 3 weeks for delivery

About Daniel Reynolds
Daniel explores the dichotomy between the traditional and contemporary and the natural and synthetic in his beautiful hand-built porcelain and stoneware work.

He recreates both organic and man-made forms using hand-built moulds to create stunningly natural, organically shaped forms.  More recently, Daniel has been working on these series of hand built pots in various sizes and glazes.

Daniel has had number of solo shows and is an internationally acclaimed ceramicist, having shown his work in Spain, Venezuela, Sweden and the UK.
